Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from economy to business class. In this room, I saw the biggest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player I had encountered, and surprising things like Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture that a teenager had bought. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting school. During this time, he wanted to become a famous composer like Richard Rodgers.
I also had big dreams; I wanted to be a pop star for the usual reasons: women, money, and fame. But my dreams were not as important to me as Andrew's were to him. When Andrew suggested that I try to become a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I was open to it. This was partly because, after just ten minutes of meeting him, he played me three of his own songs on the piano, and I could tell he was very talented.
As he played more songs from the shows he had created at school, I remembered some of the best albums from my parents' collection. He needed a new lyricist, and I didn’t have much to show him except for my praise for his music and a single I had written with a little-known pop group that had not done well. We agreed to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in theater, but I thought I had met someone special who would be very successful in musical theater soon. Even if we didn’t become top composers, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later in the summer.
The next day, back at my office where I was training to be a lawyer, the excitement I felt about working with Andrew had faded a bit. I would still look for ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a singer and write more simple songs. But it was likely that I would finish my exams and become a lawyer by twenty-five. My father thought I would stop enjoying pop music by twenty-one, which worried me because that meant I only had a few months left to enjoy it. But I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to go to a musical with him and write lyrics for musicals instead of pop songs. Andrew was an interesting person who talked about good food and old buildings, and he supported the Leyton Orient football team.
I wasn’t sure about the musical idea he had been working on for a year, but in 1965, I often doubted things. His talent was clear, and he said he had many important contacts. I soon found myself back in his living room. The idea was about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a man from the 19th century who started orphanages. His story was important, but it didn’t excite me much. The main character seemed too perfect, and the idea felt unoriginal, similar to the popular show, Oliver.
However, Andrew was very confident about his music, and his excitement was contagious. I didn’t know much about musicals, but as someone once said, if there is one hamburger place, there can be another. We could be the second one. I started working hard, especially on the funny songs. Andrew explained the story, played me the music, and often gave me the song titles, which were probably thought up by his friend from school. I even skipped a day at the law office, pretending to be sick, to write my first lyrics for the musical. I didn’t know it then, but I was starting a new career.

**Language**  
You and I are part of a special group of beings that can communicate with each other very well. Language is so important in our lives that it is hard to think of life without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will likely start talking to each other. When people are alone, they often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct'. This means that people know how to talk, just like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders do not need to learn how to spin webs from someone else; they just know how to do it.
**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather, which are mostly created by the air around us, greatly affect the lives of animals and plants. Climate can change how landscapes look. For example, warm and wet weather all year allows tropical jungles to grow, which are full of many different species. On the other hand, cold and windy places have fewer living things. The daily weather we experience is caused by large air movements, as the atmosphere is always changing. Some of this movement happens because the air is on a spinning Earth. Since air is light, it does not move as fast as the Earth, so it tends to lag behind. The sun is also a big reason for air movement.
**Coffee**  
As a bar-person, my job included serving drinks, but I was also responsible for making coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on how good its coffee is. I spent several days learning how to make coffee, including how to clean and take care of the restaurant's espresso machine. I also learned how to make a great cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized that making good coffee was harder than it seemed, and I thought I might have to go back to cleaning ashtrays. Luckily, my boss was patient. He told me, "Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn it."

**Art on TV**
Why does television often have problems with programs about visual arts? Painting and sculpture are great subjects for the camera because it can show the whole artwork and then zoom in to see the details. However, there are not many TV series that show the joy and complexity of looking at art. 
A good example of this is Robert Hughes's series called *American Visions*, which has eight parts. Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality, and he has almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which British galleries often ignore. I thought the series would focus on famous artworks, but instead, it looked at how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known as a speculator. The metals market has fewer rules than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, it is possible to make a lot of money. Taking risks is part of this business. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market global economy. 
However, the free-trade economists who believed that the market would keep the prices of rare metals high have found the opposite is true. More minerals are being mined, and the prices of raw materials are going down. When we consider inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a large company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its nearby cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, which stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island has its own character and something special to offer. To get around the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If a boat is not included with your room, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis available. You can also rent boats if you want to explore on your own. 
Sailing is the most popular way to travel here. Abaco is known as 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for good reasons. The calm, protected waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles, looking like a string of pearls. At night, the lights from the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly, adding to the beauty of the area.

**Build Your Own Bamboo Bike at the UK’s First Workshop**
You can build your own bamboo bike at the Bamboo Bike Club in the UK. This workshop is run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan. When you join a course, you get a custom bike frame designed by a computer and a fun weekend of bike-building.
It is Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London. The Bamboo Bike Club is the only place in Britain where you can learn to build bamboo bikes. I went to see what was happening. There was a lot of energy and fun in the air. Bamboo is becoming popular for making bikes again. Companies like Calfee Design from California and Bamboo Bikes from Yorkshire have been making bamboo bikes since 1894. However, many cyclists find these bikes too expensive. A ready-made bamboo frame can cost around $2,995 or £1,868.
James and Ian wanted to create a bamboo bike business that everyone could afford. They spent years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales, to make this happen. They wanted to share the joy of making something special and sustainable. So, they created the Bamboo Bike Club, which is more about community than just business. Both James and Ian have other full-time jobs; James makes wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer.
The Bamboo Bike Club offers monthly courses where you can build your own bike frame at a good price. On the first day, James and Ian teach you how to choose strong bamboo and how to make strong joints. You start by putting together the front triangle of the bike, then the seat and chain parts. Some metal tubes are added for the handlebars and other parts that need extra strength.
Building the bike can be challenging, especially if you are not used to DIY projects. James and Ian help everyone by checking each cut and joint. They are friendly and encourage you to try again if you make a mistake. The bamboo used in the workshop is checked for quality, so you can choose how your bike will look: plain bamboo, black, or mottled.
On Sunday, you spend time building the lugs, which are the parts that connect the frame. You wrap the joints with hemp and glue them to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, your bike is ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and any personal touches. James and Ian say their bamboo bikes are just as strong as metal bikes. Ian has used his bike for over a year, and James has tested his bike off-road for three months without breaking it.
The bamboo bikes may not look as polished as professional ones, but they are unique. James and Ian believe that the special look of each bike is important. I think bamboo bikes are great for relaxed rides rather than racing. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a smooth ride. When I tried James's bike, it felt light and smooth, even on bumpy roads.
James says that some people enjoy building the bike, but the real fun is riding it. Bamboo bikes are light and easy to ride, making them enjoyable. And the best part? The price is less than £500.

**Self-Help Books**
Diane Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a book by a new pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. She thought the title was great and believed it would be a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray became very successful, and Diane started her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps people understand each other better in relationships and is part of a big self-help industry in America. This industry tries to meet people's desires for improvement and also creates new needs. It supports the publishing world in New York. 
In Britain, people are discovering that many self-help books are not very good, but many more are rejected because they are too similar or too specific. This is a good thing. Editors are now looking for the next popular book, and they care more about how marketable a book is than how well it is written. Diane says that if someone has a catchy title, it makes it easier to attract readers.
**Autobiographies**
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an unspoken agreement that they will tell the truth. However, this agreement is often not fully kept. Writers may leave out things they feel are too embarrassing or not important. Sometimes, they might invent stories that express their truth better than just sticking to the facts. They might even call their book an autobiography just to make readers believe it is true, even if it is mostly fiction. This can happen without any bad intentions.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
People who study detective stories say that this genre grew because of the problems in society in the late 1800s and early 1900s. A detective story often shows a crime that represents human feelings like greed or desire. Solving the crime helps bring order back to society. In Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal are two sides of the same person. They understand each other and have a strange connection. The detective is seen as too honest by criminals and too shady by the law. His job is complicated because he feels connected to both sides.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is one of the best science writers today. I met him at the Grand Hotel while he was promoting his new book. We both felt out of place there. Gould believes that to write well about science, you need to understand the scientific community. If you don’t know the culture, it is hard to write about it. He advises writers to never talk down to their readers. You can make the language easier to understand, but you should not change the main ideas. If readers feel like they are being treated as less intelligent, they will lose interest in the writing.

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym, a popular place for City of London workers during lunch, it feels very cold inside. To handle the high summer temperatures, the gym has turned the air-conditioning up too much. Sometimes, it feels like being in the Arctic! This shows how people often misuse air-conditioning today. It is now a common part of our work and leisure, showing how we try to control the climate. However, many buildings could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and fresh air, and have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas might seem simple, but they can really help and would reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, more people are interested in sundials. Sundials are tools that tell time by using the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were very important for keeping time. But as clocks and watches became better, sundials were mostly seen as garden decorations. Now, they are being taken seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks people like them because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a special moment when a sundial starts to work. They are calm and beautiful objects that remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
My idea of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts show long ago. There, I saw serious-looking older women painting delicate flowers on teacups with great skill. It was amazing to watch them, as each brushstroke created a perfect petal or leaf. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. I thought these women must have practiced for many years or had a special talent. Because of this, I wondered what kind of people would join a china-painting class. Would beginners be good at it? When I attended a class, I found it was not scary at all. Everyone was there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint flowers as quickly as I had remembered.

**The Wrong Country**
Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price. They had a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice, a beautiful city, at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency to book the trip, the clerk told them that the other people in their group were a school group from the south coast, all learning Italian.
But something went wrong. At the travel agency, the check-in desk, or maybe in a computer, a mistake happened. Instead of going to Venice, Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss in Switzerland. At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. An hour later, they were surprised to hear older people on the plane speaking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there might have been a cancellation or that the Italian class was on another plane.
After they landed, a woman with glasses told them to stay together. The brochure did not mention an overnight stop, but when they arrived at the hotel, it was close to midnight. They were tired and did not question the beds they were given. However, the next morning, they found out they were supposed to stay in that hotel for their whole holiday, and they became worried.
The receptionist smiled and said they could enjoy the lake and take a boat to Interlaken. Keith calmly told him there had been a mistake. They were supposed to be in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. The receptionist did not know that place. Dawne added that the man who booked their trip was bald, wore glasses, and had a moustache. She also mentioned the travel agency in London.
Then, a woman named Mrs. Franks, who had been on the plane, approached them. She said she was married to a man with a bad leg. Dawne asked if she was in charge because they were in the wrong hotel. Keith explained that they had followed the girl in the yellow-and-red uniform and ended up in the wrong group. Dawne added that they should have known something was wrong when they heard people talking about Darlington instead of Dover.
Mrs. Franks explained that there are many different holidays offered by the travel agency, and all tickets look similar. She laughed and said if they followed others with the yellow-and-red label, they might end up in a wildlife park, but that could never happen. Keith insisted they were not supposed to be in Switzerland.
Mrs. Franks then walked away, leaving them confused. The receptionist was gone, and they could hear typing. Dawne whispered that Mrs. Franks seemed kind, but Keith was not paying attention. He thought about everything that had happened: giving the tickets, waiting, and getting on the plane.
An elderly man named Mr. Nottage interrupted Keith's thoughts. He and his wife, both in their eighties, said they had a great night's sleep because of the fresh air by the lake. Dawne replied that was nice. Keith and Dawne left the hotel reception without saying anything to each other about the irony of their situation. They had planned a holiday to escape the demands of older people, but they found themselves on a tour with them instead. Uncle had said the same thing when they tried to convince him to join them.

**He Was a People Person**
American business leaders are looking to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a good example of management. Eluned Price reports.
Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. However, America has only recently discovered him. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton "an Antarctic explorer whose achievements went mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which is not entirely true. Now, Americans are showing great interest in him. Many books about Shackleton and his famous voyage on the Endurance are being published. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and a film about Shackleton's life is being made.
Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They talk about his actions with great respect and find lessons in his leadership and communication skills. They even refer to each other as "speaking Shackleton." Shackleton, known for his determination and resourcefulness, has become a model for modern management consultants.
Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at a New York firm, has looked up to Shackleton for years. His firm focuses on communication during business mergers and crises. For example, they deal with situations like "the factory exploded" or "we have to lay off half the workers." While it may seem hard to connect Shackleton's survival skills in extreme cold to managing a business crisis, MacGregor believes Shackleton is a great example of a leader. 
Shackleton had strong values and was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, including their lives. One of his most interesting decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This choice showed his commitment to his men’s safety. In a crisis, people want to know who is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was willing to take charge.
His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually sank. When the ship went down, Shackleton told his men, "We should all reach safety if you do your best and trust me." From the diaries kept during the journey, it is clear that Shackleton was always in control. 
MacGregor explains that Shackleton planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and listened to their opinions. He was flexible and ready to change plans if needed. Shackleton believed that an explorer must have optimism, strength, and patience. MacGregor notes that in difficult times, especially in America, people often want quick solutions. For example, if you invest in bonds and make a mistake, it is better to wait for the situation to improve rather than sell and lose money. 
Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the photographer, without gloves. He insisted Hurley wear his gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if he didn’t. Another time, during a 1905 expedition when food was scarce, Shackleton offered to leave a biscuit in the snow instead of eating it himself, saying it was worth more than money.
As Caroline Alexander, the author of "Endurance," says, "People are increasingly interested in heroic efforts. Shackleton shows that true heroism is rare today. He stands out as a real example of the ideals we long for."

**Tapping into a Food Supply**
In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. This primate has a way of finding food that is similar to how a woodpecker does. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker look for insects by digging into wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye, however, uses its sharp front teeth to chew into the wood and its long third finger to reach inside and get the insects.
Scientists have studied the aye-aye's feeding habits for many years. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University has been observing three aye-ayes: two males named Nosferatu and Poe, and a female named Samantha with her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to find out how they find insects hidden in the wood.
Dr. Erickson first checked if the aye-ayes could see signs of insects, like holes in the wood where insects might have entered. He gave them logs with holes he had made. Some holes led to food, while others were just empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the food, showing they did not need to see the holes to find it. They might have been using their sense of smell or hearing, but more tests showed they did not need these senses either. They could find food even when the smell was blocked and when the insects were dead and silent.
So, how did the aye-ayes find the insects? Dr. Erickson found that they could sense the empty spaces in the wood. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its long finger and listens carefully. Dr. Erickson thinks the aye-aye is using a method called echo-location, where it listens for sounds that tell it there is a hollow space below. It can also hear insects moving when they are disturbed.
Some people think the aye-aye acts like a woodpecker in Madagascar, but there are also birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that look for insects in wood. So, the woodpecker role may not be empty. The aye-aye is unique because it combines features of both woodpeckers and bats, and it also behaves like a squirrel. Its front teeth keep growing like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild chewing through nuts and using its long finger to get the nut meat inside.

**Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives**
Many of us have pictures of our grandparents, but how many of us really know what their lives were like? We might have some old diaries or family stories, but they often don’t tell us everything. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write down our stories, but we don’t always do it. Sometimes we leave videos instead of photos, but videos can’t show everything.
Hannah Renier has found a solution. She writes autobiographies for other people, creating a book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if needed. She focuses on ordinary people, not famous ones. Hannah got this idea after talking to her family and realizing that many stories from the past were being forgotten. She says, "When I started, I didn’t take it seriously, but after meeting people with interesting lives, I changed my mind. They often say they are doing it for their children, but they enjoy it too."
People feel safe sharing their stories with Hannah because she keeps everything private. One man, who is 62 years old, said, "I felt free to be honest. I talked about painful things, like my divorce." He wrote his story for his family, but he hasn’t let his children read it yet because he wants to protect them from some details. He thinks it might be better for them to read it after he is gone.
Hannah has noticed that many people are influenced by their parents. She says, "It’s surprising how much childhood experiences affect people for the rest of their lives. They often repeat the same mistakes or choose partners their parents would like or rebel against them." Many people still feel regret about things that happened long ago, and they carry these feelings into adulthood.
Hannah listens more than she asks questions. She says, "I’m not here to judge or be nosy. Sometimes people share something and then worry if it should be included. I usually keep it in, but they can change it later." People want to be honest about their lives, even the difficult parts.
Hannah’s work is not about showing off. She believes that as life moves quickly, we forget our past. Writing these stories helps people connect with their roots and understand their family history. Each book takes about 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Hannah uses to write the life story. She organizes the material well and writes clearly. The final book looks good and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies available for £25 each. 
Hannah gets about 10 requests each week, but the price stops many people from ordering. She thought her service would be cheaper, but the people who have used her service are often from wealthy backgrounds. They are the kind of people who would have had their portraits painted in the past to pass down to their families.

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has a large collection of over six hundred copies of Greek and Roman sculptures. It is important to know that none of the sculptures are real; they are all replicas made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a specially designed building with great natural light. The benefit of these plaster casts is that you can see groups of sculptures that were originally together, even if they are now in different museums across Europe. You can see many famous Greek and Roman sculptures in just one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery that shows different photography exhibitions. We offer courses and workshops for people of all ages and skill levels, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with professional photographers. We have a membership program that allows members to use our darkrooms. We also support young photographers (ages 12 to 16) to improve their skills through our Young Members program, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books and magazines, as well as a full range of photography materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a wonderful collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all over the world and from different geological ages. It also has Britain's oldest geological collection, created by Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). This collection has nearly 10,000 rare specimens stored in their original cabinets from the early 18th century. Adam Sedgwick was a Professor of Geology and helped to grow the collection, making it a great museum. The collection is organized by geological age, showing how life on Earth has changed over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with labels that explain what they are and how they are used today.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
The collection has over 400,000 air photographs taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The University has its own aircraft based at Cambridge Airport and takes photographs all over Great Britain. These photographs are interesting because they show the landscape and how it has changed due to nature and human activity from prehistoric times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. You cannot borrow the photographs, but you can usually buy copies, which take about a month to make.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world. It is a unique tourist attraction where you can have fun creating wall hangings by rubbing over one of more than a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The center makes resin copies, called facsimiles, to protect the original plates while allowing everyone to enjoy brass rubbing. These brass plates were used as memorials and spread from Germany to medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many beautiful brass plates were destroyed during various revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, with the largest variety found at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Fatherhood**
**A. The Theatre Director**  
I have had a strange personal life, but I have enjoyed 35 years with small children. This morning, I fed the baby, and that is what being a father means to me. I feel very lucky with my children. We all love the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This has created a strong bond between us, especially now that they are mostly grown up and I feel more like a friend than a father. I do not believe in hitting children. I have slapped my kids in anger before, but I do not think it is right. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be there for them. I am available if they need me, but I do not chase them to ask why they haven’t called. I think that makes them feel guilty, and I would never want to do that to my children.
**B. The Advertising Executive**  
I was young when my children were born, around 25 years old. I found the responsibilities hard at first, but they also kept me feeling young. As they became teenagers, they showed me new things like music and fashion, which helped me in my job. I missed some important moments when they were younger, like their first concerts and sports days, and I feel sad about that. However, now I can take them on holidays to nice places like the south of France. They get along well with my friends and come to parties and work events without feeling nervous. I think it helps that my job is seen as interesting.
**C. The Politician**  
My first child was born just before I started my political career. My wife and I promised to spend time with our children, but as my work became busier, it became harder to find time. I only accept weekend meetings if my kids can come with me. This way, they can see what I do when I am not with them, and they do not feel like I am disappearing. I have noticed that more politicians are bringing their kids to work. Maybe we are all realizing how important it is to include our children in our lives.
**D. The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young, so I had to think more about being a father. I tried hard to stay close to them. My ex-wife and I even lived next to each other for a while so they could visit easily, but I think that confused them. Kate has said I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated my kids like adults too soon. Kate recently said we were too relaxed as parents. I think I should have set more rules. I still worry about my daughters, no matter how old they are. In that way, your children never really leave you.
**E. The TV Presenter**  
I was ready for kids when I turned 30. I had met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new things?" Having my daughter, Betty, has helped me understand who I am. It feels special to have a child, but it also makes you just one of many parents. Sometimes I feel frustrated, but just one smile from her makes everything better. A baby's smile is the best way to feel happy.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**
A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
This play by Marlowe is about a powerful warrior. It can feel very long, but Terry Hands' version makes it exciting. He has cut parts of the text to make the show faster and more energetic. Antony Sher plays the main character and gives a great performance, doing impressive stunts while speaking. The audience is captivated by his intense desire for power.  
Location: Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)
B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by Michael Wall is now in London after being shown in Manchester. The first part creates a tense feeling as two married couples talk on a sunny lawn. In the second part, the story changes and shows the serious effects of illness. Wall was a talented writer who sadly passed away at a young age.  
Location: Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)
C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche is a new Irish playwright who tells stories set in Wexford. His latest play looks at the problems in the fishing industry, mixing deep emotions with funny moments. Sometimes the story feels a bit slow, but it builds up to an exciting ending.  
Location: Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)
D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a traditional thriller about a "perfect murder." Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play two crime writers who want to kill each other. Although the story is familiar, it has clever twists and turns.  
Location: Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)
E. **The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about tricksters from the 17th century. This show, which was first seen in Stratford, is also great on the Barbican stage, with strong performances from Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce as the con-artists.  
Location: Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)
F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society is now in London after being successful at the Edinburgh Festival. The staging is stylish, the acting is excellent, and the play is a classic that deserves more attention.  
Location: Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)
G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn tells a version of Beauty and the Beast set in a London suburb. It has beautiful music by John Pattison and celebrates romantic love, making it a charming show.  
Location: Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)
H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy is not very impressive, but it has great performances from Ron Cook as Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as the jealous husband, Ford. Other actors seem a bit uncomfortable.  
Location: Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)
I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
This is another important revival of Granville Barker's work, now touring. It tells the story of a respectable lawyer who leaves a corrupt legacy to his son, resulting in a wonderful play.  
Location: Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)

**Hide and Seek**  
Yvonne Coppard  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game where they watch a strange bookshop. Emma sees that her Uncle Jim is one of the few customers. He tricks her and tries to turn her against her friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes very serious. She is trapped in the cellar of an old house. This book shows family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always safe. It is an important and interesting read.
**Backtrack**  
Peter Hunt  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together when they find out that their relatives were involved in a train accident in 1915, where eight people died. They look at different documents like maps and personal stories to understand what happened. This clever and complex novel makes the reader think hard about the mystery.
**Pigeon Summer**  
Ann Turnbull  
Mary Dyer feels out of place in her family and society. She loves her father's racing pigeons, and when he leaves for work, she takes care of them and wins prizes, even though her mother is upset. Set in 1930, this story teaches that "There are different kinds of cleverness." Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.
**Yaxley's Cat**  
Robert Westall  
In this chilling story, a woman named Rose rents a cottage to escape her unhappy life with her husband. She brings her two children with her. A fierce cat and strange things in the cottage help explain why the last owner, Sepp Yaxley, disappeared. However, the locals do not welcome them, and their lives are in danger. By the end, the violence is under control, but Rose is troubled by her son's behavior. It is a gripping story.
**Someone's Mother is Missing**  
Harry Mazer  
Sam is a chubby and talkative boy who admires his cool cousin, Lisa, who comes from a wealthy family. When Lisa's life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and they both learn the importance of family. The story moves slowly at times, but it has gentle humor and shows the growing friendship between the two teenagers. It can appeal to both boys and girls.
**Stanley's Aquarium**  
Barry Faville  
Barry Faville writes with confidence and humor, bringing his New Zealand setting to life. Robbie takes a job gardening for an old man named Stanley. At first, she finds him interesting, but later he becomes strange. When she discovers what he keeps in his aquarium and his plans, the story takes a thrilling turn while still exploring character and relationships. It is unusual and engaging.
**Dodger**  
Libby Gleeson  
This is a sad story about Mick, who has troubled relationships and a difficult school life. The story is told through flashbacks, letters from a teacher, and Mick's own notes. He learns to deal with the negative views of others and his low self-esteem through a school play and the help of a caring teacher. It is highly recommended, even though it is a painful read, especially at the end.

**Science Flying in the Face of Gravity**
Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are testing their ideas in weightlessness. The aircraft looked normal from the outside. The pilot told the 13 students from Europe and America that it was built in 1964 and was a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker, based on the Boeing 707. But inside, it was very different. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows and bright lights along the padded walls. Most of the seats were removed, except for a few at the back where the nervous students sat.
For a year, these students had competed to join this flight, which was a challenge from the European Space Agency. They had to come up with creative experiments to do in weightlessness. The students with the best ideas won a spot on this special flight, which was like the most exciting roller-coaster ride.
For the next two hours, the flight would feel like a big bird flying up and down. The pilot would cut the engines at 3,000 meters, and the plane would go higher for a moment before falling back to Earth. During the few seconds of weightlessness, the students would feel like they were closer to the moon than to the ground.
The plane took off smoothly, but that changed quickly when the pilot made the plane climb steeply for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, and we felt heavy as blood rushed from our heads. Then, the engines stopped, and we suddenly felt weightless. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence, like we were on a trampoline. Moving around was confusing because up and down didn’t mean anything anymore.
After ten seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. Gravity returned, but not as quickly as it had left, and some students landed hard. After the first curve, some students felt sick thinking about the 29 more to come. The flight included thirty curves, giving the students ten minutes of weightlessness for their experiments.
The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They released a device to help with this, and one student managed to turn it over using a remote control. However, another student accidentally landed on it during a curve, almost breaking it.
A German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joints are affected by weightlessness, which could help build future space stations. Another group from Utah State University worked on creating solar sails from thin liquid films that harden in sunlight. They believe that if they succeed, satellites could use solar sails like yachts use wind.
After two hours of flying between heaven and Earth, the students felt excited rather than sick. One student said, "It was an unforgettable experience. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**
**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*.
I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer, which is actually winter there. So, I had nine winters in a row, which was great because I like winter. My parents had the idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you plant trees on it, you can have it.” The idea was that we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which is nice because my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land is not very good, but it is good for planting trees.
I have always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing different farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees excited me. I think my family became more enthusiastic as we went along. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted the whole 70 acres together.
In New Zealand in 1968, it rained a lot during that winter. It is funny to think of it as a happy time because it rained almost every day we were planting. I don’t think I have ever been so wet and cold for such a long time. Every morning was a challenge: getting ready for the next planting session. I would come out of the Land Rover warm and dry, but the rain would be pouring down. My jacket was still damp from the day before, my boots were soaked, and my hands struggled with slippery laces. 
In that first year, I had a helper who was an experienced tree-planter, which was very helpful because I had never planted trees seriously before. You wear a planting bag around your neck and fill it with as many trees as you can. When the bag is full, it is heavy, but it gets easier as it gets lighter. The hardest part was getting the lines straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then you line up three poles to guide you. Once you are in line, you just plant all the way down the line, turn around, and come back.
I enjoy hard physical work, and it helped me get fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically. You get used to a rhythm and use the least number of spade strokes to dig the hole. This rhythm is important in many farming jobs. You train your body to do the same moves, and then it becomes easy: you take the tree out of the bag, dig a hole, put it in the ground, stamp it down, and move on. 
Mentally, it is interesting. My mind starts to think about many things, including nature and our place in it. A lot of my thoughts about these topics began during that time. I have been back to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which is very satisfying because I planted them. I feel a connection to what happens to them. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such news makes me anxious. However, everything worked out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy.
I should add that I took a break from teaching and went back in 1984 for three months by myself. I wrote my first book there, *Seeing Green*. There is a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I would write; in the afternoons, I would prune the trees, and in the evenings, I would do research. My connection to that area is still very strong. It is the place I feel most connected to in terms of the bond between people and the earth.

**Bringing Up Badgers**
"What now?" was my first thought when one of my helpers brought me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have an open farm in Somerset where we care for orphaned animals. But the noise from the box was strange, so I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their soft coats were like velvet, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most badgers are born between mid-January and mid-March and live underground. If they lose their mother, they often die from hunger. These three cubs were found by builders who accidentally disturbed their home while working. Their mother was dead, but the cubs were alive, though cold and whimpering. 
After removing fleas from them, I took them into the kitchen to keep them warm. There were two females named Primrose and Bluebell, and a male named Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe them with a warm cloth to make them feel like their mother was licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. Within a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started to move around, although a bit unsteady. They were happy with each other and a heated pad that acted like their mother.
Three weeks later, I noticed Willow seemed tired, but he was still eating. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t realize it was serious. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he died from a lung infection caused by drinking too fast. I felt sad about losing him but continued to care for the other two. Then, a local farmer came to me with another male cub he had found alone. He knew the mother would not return, so I took in Willow II. He was younger than the females and very hard to feed. It took a long time to get him to drink from the bottle.
By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and other foods. Willow II was finally ready to eat solid food, but he made a mess while trying to eat. I gave him a sausage, and after a week, he was ready for more food. At almost five months old, they were all eating cereals, meat, vegetables, fruit, nuts, cheese, and eggs. Badgers usually eat a lot of earthworms, but my badgers were doing well, especially since it was a hot summer and finding food was hard.
By August, the badgers started to be active at night. We often walked through the orchard, and they would play and chase each other. I learned to avoid their playful bites, but Derek sometimes got caught and ended up with bruises. During these walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were looking for food because their own areas were disturbed. We were warned that they might come into our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we made the gate secure.
The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and many people wanted to help build a home for them on our farm. With advice from others, we designed a new home for the badgers. Our son Daniel made the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels and a special gate. It had three rooms, one bigger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside. As we built it, the badgers explored the new home before going on their walks. They soon forgot about the walks and enjoyed playing in the tunnels.
The building cost more than we expected, but a local bus company helped pay for it, and other businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted the badgers to have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle down. When I checked later, I saw three badgers curled up and sleeping.
Now, I don’t walk with them as often because they stay awake until midnight. We see Primrose only sometimes because she has joined another sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before running off into the night. This is their home now, and they have made it their own.

**In Search of True North - The Man Behind Halley's Comet**
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow the journey of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.
Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, many people at that time thought his most important work was to study the "variations of the compass." These variations, now called "declination," show the angle between magnetic north and true north. Sailors needed this information to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans accurately.
Halley was one of only two people in England paid to do scientific research. He set out for the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the North and South Atlantic. However, he had to return early because of problems with his crew. Later, he made another trip that took him to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From this journey, Halley published a map in 1701 showing compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. This map helped sailors for over a hundred years until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate.
Dr. Clark wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by retracing his route. He needs to raise £70,000 before he can start, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is helping him.
Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. He says, "Halley led a remarkable life. He was a respected scientist and led many expeditions. He was not just an astronomer; he also studied geophysics." During his time as Astronomer Royal, Halley mapped the stars and invented a diving bell. He also helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, *Principia Mathematica*.
Dr. Clark believes that recreating Halley's voyage will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also have scientific value. Dr. Clark plans to take measurements like Halley did, but with better tools. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data collected will help improve the current model of the Earth's magnetic field.
Dr. Clark explains, "We usually measure the size of the magnetic field, but not its direction. To measure direction, we need to know true north." On this expedition, they will use satellites to find true north. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the trip. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his work will fill in any gaps in the data over the Atlantic Ocean.
Halley's journey was significant because it was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he was the first civilian to be appointed as a naval captain for this purpose. 
Does Dr. Clark have what it takes to succeed in his journey? He has spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed the 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.
Does he share Halley's passion? He says, "I am ready to give up eight months of my life for this, so some might think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn’t want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his amazing life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**POWER DRESSING**
Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful feathers to the hens. This behavior has puzzled scientists like Charles Darwin. He wondered how birds could develop such extravagant features in a world where survival is tough. 
Darwin believed that animals change over time through evolution, not by special creation. He thought that the strongest and best-adapted animals survive and have babies. However, he found it hard to explain why peacocks have such large tails, which can be a disadvantage. He introduced the idea of "sexual selection," suggesting that females choose males based on their beauty.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different view. He believed that if peahens liked the most colorful peacocks, it meant those peacocks had some hidden quality that helped them survive. 
Now, 100 years later, scientists are still studying this question. At Whipsnade, there are 200 peacocks that live like wild birds but are used to people. Researchers, led by Marion Petrie, are trying to answer two main questions: Do peahens really prefer the peacocks with the most beautiful tails? And do these peacocks have other advantages, or is it just about looks?
The researchers have observed that peahens seem to prefer males with more eye spots on their tails. These peacocks attract more mates. However, it is still unclear if these attractive males are better in other ways. 
William Hamilton from Oxford University suggested that showy male birds might be healthier and have fewer parasites. This idea has been supported in other bird species, but the researchers at Whipsnade have not yet been able to check the health of their peacocks.
This year, Dr. Petrie is studying the babies of attractive and unattractive peacocks to see if the attractive ones grow faster and are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that females choose males for practical reasons.
There is also an interesting theory from mathematician R A Fisher. He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, her sons will inherit that tail, and her daughters will prefer long tails. Over time, this could lead to peacocks having very long tails. This idea also supports Darwin's view that females might choose beauty for its own sake.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He showed this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of beautiful yachts with new technology. Most of these boats come from a big change in boat design that happened 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly resting in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. You might think its owner is a romantic person. Maybe I am, but I’m not sure.
My boat uses the best parts of old boat design, but modern technology has made it easier to build. However, even though technology is important in boat design, it often keeps sailors away from the real challenges of life at sea. These challenges are often what sailors want to experience when they go to sea. I don’t think sailors should go back to suffering through every difficulty. I believe it is important for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable places to sleep. But why go sailing if everything is done for you? Dealing with sails that flap in the wind is part of being a sailor.
Also, why should we change the steering position from a safe place at the back of the boat to a less safe spot in the middle? This change makes the inside of the boat feel like a big house, with a bed bigger than the one at home. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a house on the water.
When I bought my first boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race, the previous owner said it had all the comforts but no luxury. I learned how true this was during my time with Hirta. She had heavy sails, no running water, little electricity, no fridge, no central heating, and no electronics for navigation. Still, she was the easiest boat I ever sailed.
However, classic boats like Hirta need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I knew I had to stop sailing her. I looked for a younger boat but couldn’t find one, so I decided to build a new boat from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although the designer, Nigel Irens, and his assistant, Ed Burnett, use computer programs, Irens first drew the boat on a paper napkin and then moved to the computer. After creating a model, we worked together to improve the design. The final version was perfect.
The Westerman has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She looks timeless, moves beautifully in the sea, and has a peaceful atmosphere inside, made from reclaimed pitch pine. This is because she was designed only as a sailing boat, without thinking about furniture. This traditional method works well. The Westerman shows that you don’t need to follow trends to be happy, and sometimes it’s good to learn from the past. Made from wood treated with special glue, she is completely waterproof. So, she has the advantages of a fiberglass boat but still looks, feels, and sails like a real boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**
Health farms and country house hotels with spa services are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was happy to spend six days at Henlow Grange because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started taking classes like yoga and body conditioning. The instructors were very skilled. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment, which lasts an hour, made me feel like a new person. The staff were friendly and professional. The atmosphere was full of energy. Henlow is planning to improve the facilities this year, including a new swimming pool. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you want to relax, you can read a magazine or take a quiet walk in the garden. During my stay, I felt happier and had a better appetite. I left feeling great and full of energy. I would love to visit again. This is a perfect place for busy women. Save Room 5 for me!  
*Marcella D'Argy Smith*
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
The peaceful atmosphere of this stately home was clear as soon as I entered. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library and a lovely conservatory, with plenty of space to relax alone. When you arrive, everyone gets a medical check-up, including weight and blood pressure. They called us patients, which felt strange since I am healthy. However, I was impressed that they quickly addressed a shoulder problem I had. Each person gets a special diet to follow. I lost weight without starving, but I was still hungry and got a headache on the second day. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you are not on a diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty. You can enjoy a massage or water therapy every other day. Extra treatments are available at reasonable prices.  
*Liz Gregory*
**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys is not a health farm, but a lovely old manor with cozy log fires and a big lounge. If you are counting calories, you might want to skip the gourmet food, which is rich and delicious. Luckily, the hotel has a gym and a soft-water pool to help you stay active. There is also a spa bath, steam room, sauna, and treatment rooms. A popular service is the sports injury clinic. I got advice for an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture and exercises. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, but also relaxed. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around.  
*Beverly D'Silva*
**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful walks and gardens in the 376-acre estate. The restaurant, Waldo's, has amazing food. It took me a long time to read the dinner menu because there were so many choices. The meal was fantastic, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed very happy! The next morning, I spent some time in the gym to burn off some calories. I enjoyed a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has everything you need for fitness and beauty before you treat yourself at Waldo's.  
*Kay Letch*
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is the most delicious cake I have ever had, but it has a lot of calories, which is not good if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the wonderful aromatherapy massage. I chose relaxing oils and fell asleep during the massage. I had the best sleep in years. The place is modern and well-organized, with great facilities and comfortable rooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, so it is easy to book treatments. They offer a variety of services, from manicures to deep-cleansing facials. The guests are a mix of people, including football teams, mothers and daughters, friends, and singles. I would love to take a break here every month.  
*Eve Cameron*

**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not changed much. Genetically, we are still over 98% similar to chimps. This means that the differences between humans and animals are very recent. Our ability to create art and other things we think are unique to humans comes from just a small part of our genes. 
Recent studies show that many traits once thought to be only human are also found in animals. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language, with different sounds for warnings like 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. This means that there are not many clear differences between humans and animals, except for art.
If human art comes from a special genetic ability, it is strange that our ancestors did not create art for almost seven million years after separating from chimps. The first forms of art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. The first clear evidence of human art appears around 35,000 years ago with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.
If we believe that our recent creativity makes us different, we need to think about how our art is different from animal art. Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it is made for beauty, and it is learned rather than instinctive.
First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. While some human art communicates ideas, this is not the same as passing on genes. For example, birds sing to defend their territory or attract a mate, which helps them pass on their genes. By this idea, human art does seem different.
The second claim is that human art is motivated by the desire for beauty. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mainly sing during mating season, so they might not sing just for beauty. Again, this makes human art seem unique.
The third claim is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from those in Paris. People can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' song, even if they have never heard it before.
Human art changes quickly. For example, people can easily tell that a painting from the 20th century is different from the famous Mona Lisa. Art experts can often identify when and who painted a work. However, two chimpanzees named Congo and Betsy created paintings that some experts might mistake for human art. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and was upset when his pencil was taken away. Their paintings were shown in a gallery in London in 1957, and many sold, which is something many human artists cannot achieve.
These chimpanzee paintings blur the lines between human art and animal behavior. Like human art, the ape paintings were not created for practical reasons; they were made for the satisfaction of the painter. Some might argue that human art is different because it is meant to communicate, while the apes did not care about sharing their art. However, even some famous human art was created for personal satisfaction, not to communicate with others.

**An Awfully Big Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed this desert and lived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. In the past, children's stories were about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and narrow eyes, looking into the unknown. Today, we do not see such people in stories or in real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's big adventure was leading a group across the Taklamakan Desert. Its name means "once entered, you never come out," but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey while sitting calmly at home with his family. 
The team he led had four British people (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have been very dangerous and could have ruined the expedition.
This mixed group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the world's toughest desert, and Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to learn more about himself. "I always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but I suddenly wanted to see who I really was outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn’t come back because nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what would happen. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very good to us."
Anyone reading his amazing story will be surprised by the word "good." The team faced many hardships: sickness, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and losing part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We did not face the famous sandstorms of the Taklamakan. And we did not experience the freezing cold that could have stopped us completely. However, we were always fighting against challenges. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and for the heavy camels, which often fell over onto us."
"What pushed me on more than anything was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time did not allow for one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we got into the sandhills, we were completely alone. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared about my physical ability. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do it now!' At that moment, I was very scared."
If it was hard at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking for 1,000 kilometers, you are not going to give up. You have gone through so much; you have so much behind you. We were very thin but also very strong despite being tired. My body was fit, and my legs were strong. I could walk over anything."
In the middle of the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon and thinking about his family. How did he feel about what they went through? "Inside me, there is someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the image of the desert and remember that we managed to do that together. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I have done. But when I think about my life, I think of my family and the happiness we share. Compared to that, the desert does not measure up."
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge and the open spaces. We felt a strong sense of purpose. Now, I find it hard to be part of the sameness of modern life."

Life Without Gadgets**
Susan Harr decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us useful devices that make life easier. However, Susan feels that we have become too dependent on technology. She believes that using gadgets can sometimes cause more problems than they solve.
Recently, her word processor broke, and she had to pay a lot of money to fix it. This made her think about how much we rely on technology. She started to let go of some household gadgets as they broke down. She wonders if the time we save with technology is really worth it. Does it just mean we have more things to buy?
When her broken gadget made strange noises, she decided to leave it outside. Now, she enjoys sewing by hand instead of using a machine. She feels free and can take her sewing with her wherever she goes. While she appreciates some gadgets, like her washing machine, she has found joy in doing things without them.
For example, she returned her rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This change helped her family spend more time walking the dog, reading, and talking to each other. She also stopped using her sewing machine and now sews by hand, which she finds relaxing.
Sewing by hand allows her to listen to the radio or talk with family while she works. She enjoys the cozy feeling of sitting by the fire with a cup of tea. At first, she thought sewing by hand would be boring and tiring, but she now finds it satisfying and calming. 
Susan realizes that she can take her time and enjoy her activities without rushing. She also finds pleasure in simple tasks like washing dishes. Now, she looks around her home and wonders if she really needs all her gadgets, like the freezer or microwave. She thinks that living without some of these devices could save her a lot of money.

The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst**
Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him in his workshop, which is under a railway arch in East London. When I arrive, he greets me quickly with a handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" It is not clear if he is always in a hurry or if he is shy. 
His workshop is busy, filled with unfinished furniture and pieces of wood in many colors. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and has a great reputation. He always has many orders, even though he does not advertise himself. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, or bookcase, Hurst is the right person to contact.
Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one who makes high-quality furniture is more difficult. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many people just call themselves furniture-makers." He is often disappointed by the quality of modern furniture. He does not like mass-produced furniture and believes that many people accept poor quality.
Hurst's desire for perfection is important for his success, along with his talent. He is confident in his skills and says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He learned his craft by asking questions and teaching himself. Most of his work comes from private clients, and some come back to him many times. He enjoys doing complete projects for their homes.
However, he admits that not all client relationships are easy. He finds it frustrating when clients do not know what they want. He prefers clients who are clear about their needs. Hurst is proud of his work but also respects other craftsmen. He says, "There are people far better than me." He did not study at a famous furniture design school, but he is critical of those who take too long to make one piece of furniture. 
He also does not like when students try to make their work look fashionable. He believes furniture should be practical and useful. Hurst is confident but not pretentious. As I leave, he reminds me, "After all, I am only making furniture."

**Three Theories About Sleep**
People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.
The first and most popular theory says that sleep is important for our body. It suggests that while we sleep, our body repairs itself and gets ready for the next day.
The second theory focuses on learning. It says that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. Without sleep, we would not be able to learn well.
The third theory talks about energy. It claims that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we can feel ready and active for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is someone whose behavior is different from what is normal in society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most people have their own strange habits or interests. For example, someone might love entering newspaper competitions, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to the press about many topics. Eccentricity shows our individuality.
Inside us, there is often a struggle between two forces: individualism and conformity. Individualism is the desire to be unique, while conformity is the desire to fit in with others. Most people want to be accepted and loved, which makes them follow the crowd instead of standing out.
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often come together. They form clubs and hold meetings to share their interests, which others might see as strange. Being part of a group can be comforting. Many of us feel a conflict between wanting to be ourselves and wanting to fit in. For example, someone might say, "I say what I think," to show they are different, or "You must take me as you find me," to show they do not care about social rules.
Anyone can choose to be more individualistic at any time. Many successful people have done this. Bob Dylan, an American singer, said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing, pursue it without giving up. This may confuse others." However, being different on purpose, like a pop singer wearing strange clothes for attention, is not true eccentricity. 
True eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. They do not care much about what others think. They act based on who they are. This makes eccentrics different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, or attention-seekers, who are aware of society and often react to it. Eccentrics, on the other hand, live their lives happily without worrying about others.

**Natural Books**
We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
It was easy for me to choose the author. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in this field. One of the most important is Barbara Ward, a small and fragile woman. She was very influential in environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from different environmental movements into her own strong ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand these issues better. Choosing her book was harder. I could have picked "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But I believe Barbara's most important book is "The Home of Man." It talks about the rapid growth of cities and important themes she cared about. It is a powerful call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none are as good as this one.
**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of their droppings in the sun. This book wonderfully explains the interesting world of animal communication with words and pictures. After reading it, if you watch a gull colony, you will see how their chaotic activity is actually a well-organized social structure. You can identify which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His work with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and interesting for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's paintings show how one gull can be aggressive while another is calm, showing the skill of a true naturalist.
**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband but also to a great career in conservation. It made me love the natural world. I was doing research on animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. After two years of challenges, reading this book made me feel hopeful again. It beautifully connects animals, people, joy, and beauty, showing a world worth saving. Some people think humans are bad because of the harm we do to other species. But I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living things as a family, showing that we are all connected. This is an important idea for everyone to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library soon after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially the 48 colorful bird paintings by Eric Ennion. These images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start sketching what I saw.
