But "The Shell Bird Book" offered much more. It had beautiful paintings, chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music, literature, and art. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. It showed me that my emotional and creative feelings about nature are just as important as scientific ones. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new opportunities for myself.

**Do Reviews Sell Books?**
We asked five important British publishers how book reviews affect a book's success. Here is what they said.
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They are the first thing we look at in newspapers. A study showed that many people said they bought a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers often think that even bad reviews can help sales. They believe that both good and bad reviews can make readers want to try the book for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own feelings about a book since they are often the first to read it.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed, especially in a good way. Book reviews today are better and more varied than they were 40 years ago. However, many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers should not complain too much because they, like readers and writers, need reviews. A good review from a trusted source can really help sell a book, especially if there are several good reviews.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for publishing. Without them, we would struggle to promote our books. Most of the books we publish are not by famous authors, so we rely on reviews from literary editors. Good reviews are often more valuable than ads because readers trust them. Publishers say they care more about the size of the review than its content. Good reviews can help a book and an author become successful, but they need support from other things like recommendations from readers and good marketing.
**Publisher D**  
I wish I understood the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain! In the United States, a single review can make or break a book. Here, bookshops often do not pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes it takes many years of good reviews for people to notice a good writer. However, some poorly reviewed books still sell very well. It is unpredictable. Non-fiction books allow reviewers to share their knowledge about the topic instead of just focusing on the book.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews. But do they really help sell books? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it did not sell well because people felt they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the name of the reviewer matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people would pay attention. Now, sometimes it is the unexpected reviewer or a unique review that encourages people to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**
Making weathervanes is an old skill that started in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith continues this craft in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who makes weathervanes by hand. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. He says, "This way, I can make a special item just for them." Many of his customers are women looking for gifts for their husbands. They want something special that shows the man's job or hobbies.
Graham's work is different from the usual cockerel design that most weathervanes have. The first weathervane he made was a witch on a broomstick for his wife. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them too. He realized there were many different ideas he could use for designs. 
Graham decided to focus on making weathervanes. Before this, he trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed their roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to take care of their children and grow his business. This was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. He says, "My old job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic. I really enjoy designing."
Graham has created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval on the design before he starts cutting it by hand. He also keeps some traditional designs available because they are still popular. Graham believes that people like handmade items because they are different.
He does not plan to grow his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. He says, "I have found my place in the market. People love unique items, and I feel satisfied when I see a simple shape turn into something beautiful." For many years, weathervanes have helped people understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction. Now, more people are moving to the countryside and want to add special touches to their homes. This has helped crafts like his.
Graham is now busier than ever, sending weathervanes to customers all over the world, especially in America and Denmark. He explains that the price depends on how detailed the design is. His latest request was for a weathervane shaped like a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**Beginner Takes All**
Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was already a very popular book. It is the first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, and it made him a lot of money. Here, he talks about his inspiration and success.
At the beginning of the year, Nicholas Evans was having a tough time. A film project he had worked on for months fell apart suddenly. He was worried because it had been two years since he earned any money, and he was in debt to the bank. A smart person in his situation would have found a job, maybe returning to television. But instead, he made a surprising choice. He bought a ticket to America to spend three months researching for his first novel.
Even though he acted on impulse, he had an idea for the story for a while. He got the idea from a farrier he met while visiting a friend. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became aggressive. The owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These people were called "horse whisperers." This story inspired Evans.
He started to research horse whisperers, thinking about writing a screenplay since he was a filmmaker. But after his film project failed, he decided to write a book instead. During the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He later said, "It was a funny time. I was observing people, but I felt alone and worried about my life. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt and unsure how to support my family."
By the end of August, he returned home and had written the first half of the book. He was still worried about money and needed to know if he should continue. He showed the book to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and thought Evans could get $30,000 as an advance for the book. Evans needed more money to pay off his debts, and he had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer*, with more work to do.
In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the novel and a 12-page summary to seven UK publishers just before the Frankfurt Book Fair. Soon, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. Evans was shocked and asked, "You what?" His agent replied, "It's OK, I just sense something is happening."
What happened next was amazing. Within a week, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. Evans and his team were in disbelief. They had not even sent the manuscript to New York, and they did not know how it got there. Major film studios also wanted the book. Evans's UK agent worked with an agent in the US, and when they said they could get $3 million for the film rights, they laughed in surprise.
That October, four famous filmmakers called Evans one after the other, asking to pay $3 million for his unfinished novel. Evans shared this story while we drank coffee on his porch, overlooking his garden. He said he turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's all been like a fairy tale," he said. "I don't want to spoil it. Writing at that level is very hard, and I don't want to become just an employee. I want to stay involved but at a distance."
His novel's success also brought new support for his film project, *Life and Limb*, but he was not sure if he wanted to make it anymore. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

**Young Masters**
Bobby Fischer is trying to return to chess, but age is not on his side. Chess is now more of a young man's game. After being away from chess for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game, which was impressive, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, out of practice, and not in great shape. Spassky is even older.
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, and now there is a professional chess circuit. Today, the main goal for players is to win. In international chess, a player’s nerves and stamina are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high. Players use a chess clock to make sure they finish their moves in time. If they don’t, they lose the game. Now, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks. This has made it harder for older players.
In the last 30 years, every new world champion has been younger than the last. Of the ten best players in the world, eight are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Many players prepare before matches, especially because computers can store many chess games and help players study their opponents. In recent matches, players have had teams of helpers working to find weaknesses in their opponent's game. The beginning of a chess game is now studied very carefully, and being well-prepared can be the key to winning.
Today, there are more great chess players than ever before. Many grandmasters compete for small prizes around the world. Success in chess requires both mental and physical effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. If they lose concentration, they can lose the game. The chess clock adds to the stress, and the end of the game can be very intense, with players racing to make their moves in just a few seconds.
At the highest level of chess, losing is very painful. Winning feels great and helps players recover from the stress. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess tournaments usually last 9 to 11 days, with games every day. World championship matches can be even tougher. For example, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in 1984 had to stop after several months because both players were exhausted.
Can Bobby Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his long absence from the game surprising. If he has come back for money, he will do well, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. But if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

**Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.
**A** Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, *Peaches*, into a movie script. He says, "It's a low budget, but we don't know how low. It won't be over £30 million, but it could be £30." The interesting thing about Nick is that before writing *Peaches*, he had never been to a play or read one. He explains, "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed. It's set in a car, and now I know that was a difficult choice." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. He realized he wanted to write for actors because he wanted his work to be heard. He says, "I was finally around people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed learning."
**B** Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is now writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tough tour with comedian Steve Coogan. Simon has always worked hard, even performing in comedy clubs while at university. He remembers, "University was very theoretical. It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor; I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, it's great to make people laugh." He has worked with the comedy group Funny Business, but his best partnership has been with Steve Coogan. Simon admits, "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed I was copying him."
**C** Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became well-known when he starred in the series *The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star*. The response was very positive, and now he can choose what projects he wants to do. He says, "It's been a great opportunity for me. I can pick and choose, which is what I've always wanted." This is impressive, especially since he just graduated. Ciaran started acting in school and then joined the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. He jokes, "I used acting to avoid doing homework. But then I decided I wanted to take it seriously because I had a talent and passion for it." Now, he is waiting for more recognition, but he reflects on fame, saying, "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you realize it's not why you act. It's about getting respect for good work."
**D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a deal for three albums. Neil and his bandmate, Rick Brown, are expected to be very successful when their single, *Chimera*, is released soon. Neil says, "The record company has a different idea of success than I do. They want a big hit, but for me, if two people buy it, I'll be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music industry since then. He shares, "It's funny how things happen. I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick, who had connections in the music business." This meeting changed everything for him. He adds, "There were times I felt very down, but I hope it will all be worth it."
**E** Stephen Richards, 27, is a poet and author who has won many awards. He is well-known in the poetry world and has been giving readings for six years. His first novel, *Hidden*, will be published in March. He describes it as a story about obsessive love, which he felt was too strong for a poem. Stephen loved creative writing in school but lost interest in education later. He decided not to go to university but changed his mind after getting bored with a job at a theatre. After university, he published his first book, a children's story, in 1992. He says, "My parents didn't expect me to be a writer; they thought I would just read." With his poetry getting great reviews, moving to novels is a big step for him. He explains, "Poetry has a structure, but novels can be any length, which means there are more chances to make mistakes. My goal is to avoid just writing a lot without caring about quality."

A. Isabel is a 31-year-old art student who thinks she looks good in jeans, but she rarely wears them. She is worried that wearing jeans might make her look like the wrong kind of person. Isabel is looking for Mr. Right and hopes that her knobbly knees won’t stop her. She stays hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes in a lively style, using chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired."
B. This story is about a local radio station in America that almost fails. It is told from the perspective of a smart, shy boy named Francis With. He works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, which was started by two brothers to promote their sandwich shop. The station plays a mix of music, sermons, and soap operas. The author uses humor and simple writing to take readers back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of old stores and classic cars.
C. In this story, it is normal for a second husband to talk to his wife’s first husband. Richard Vaisey, a successful professor, falls in love with a Russian poetess. He shares his feelings with his wife’s ex-husband. The poetess writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she wants his help for her brother who is in prison. The author skillfully tells the story with humor and insight into relationships, making it an enjoyable read.
D. In 1960s London, two sets of best friends—two women and two men—become connected for 25 years. At the beginning of the story, James Hudson, a wealthy American, is starting a newspaper with his friend Richard Blake. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that a woman they both loved, and one of them married, was killed years ago. The story includes themes of murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, and the writing is engaging. This book allows readers to really get to know the characters.
E. This story, written by a great American author, is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about something he did. To make up for it, he becomes a father figure to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is slowly becoming a quirky bachelor. The story explores many emotions and shows the special bond Ian forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm and funny book that balances sadness and laughter.

**Volunteer Tourism**
Four writers talk about international volunteer work. 
A. It is difficult to say that volunteer work really helps development a lot. Volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a lot of money to do this work. If this money was given directly to a local community, it could pay for more help than one volunteer can give. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often do not have special skills or experience. Many studies question whether these volunteers really want to help the community or if they just want to improve their own careers. However, these projects can help develop people who will act ethically and help those in need in the future.
B. Volunteering can help people understand each other better, solve conflicts, and participate in global issues through organizations. It can also create international friendships among regular people. In this way, everyone benefits, and it helps the world as a whole. But if only wealthy people can volunteer, it may help them in their careers but not help the communities that need it most. Those who volunteer may continue to benefit personally while using the communities they help.
C. Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as a form of charity that is more about helping the volunteers than the communities. It can also provide real help for development. At its best, volunteering can bring benefits to both volunteers and the organizations they work with, while also sharing skills and experiences with developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness about unfair power relations and the deep causes of poverty and injustice.
D. Volunteer tourism fits well with the idea of helping others. These small efforts to "make a difference" can seem positive, especially when people are tired of big government and businesses. However, this approach can ignore the need for democratic government and reduce development to individual acts of charity. While volunteering is often a good thing, when it is promoted as sustainable development, it can weaken the real conversation about development. The politics of volunteer tourism can distract from understanding global inequalities and the poverty many people face in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm**
Stuart Harris reports
Many people listen to the radio in the morning, and most of us need something to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? A group of us, including inventor Tom Granger and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five different models.
One model has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two different wake-up times, one for work days and one for weekends. However, it does not let you snooze and sleep longer as I thought. This model costs about the same as another one we tested, but it has a cassette player. You can listen to your favorite tapes to fall asleep and wake up without news. We all agreed that the radio quality was excellent, but the size is a problem; it is as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, "Any clock radio I buy must leave space on my bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. I always book a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn’t work."
This model was voted the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was "in love with it," even though the clock he tested sometimes got stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with its nice grey numbers on a soft green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can easily tap it with your eyes closed. However, the buttons felt nice to touch, and I ended up pressing them too much, which made it hard to understand the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if the power goes out. We all liked this feature. But we found it difficult to set up, even though learning to use it made us feel cool.
Tom Granger thought this model, which has a built-in lamp, looked cheap. He had to read the instructions twice to get it to work because the clock kept changing time. The lamp was hard to adjust, and you couldn’t read by it because it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea funny but agreed that tuning the radio was difficult. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine, and it made me want to throw the clock across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. It is aimed at young people with its bright colors, and both Tom Granger and I liked it. Tom said, "I would choose this one because it stands out."
The controls were easy to use, and we could set it up without reading the instructions. However, the alarm can go off 20 minutes earlier or later than the set time, which Paul Bridges found ridiculous. He said this model was "very complicated" and "completely useless." 
The simplest and cheapest model we tested was liked by Tom Granger because it was small and had old-fashioned dial tuning. He said, "It’s easier to set up. With modern buttons, you’re never sure if you pressed everything correctly." He agreed that radio quality has improved with new technology. I thought the tuning was not very good, and so did Paul Bridges, but we both agreed that the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs
A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. You can find hedgehogs in many parts of the world, but they are not native to America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are in danger, so their spines point outwards. This helps protect them. However, how well this works depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some hedgehogs that live in deserts have fewer spines because they have adapted to their environment. These hedgehogs are more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up.
Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They usually sleep under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. Some hedgehogs will stay awake all year if the conditions are good.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**
It is hard to be good at any sport, even for men, but women often have to work even harder. Training and competitions take a lot of time, so they have to make sacrifices. Despite this, they are overcoming challenges and breaking records. Here, we talk to some amazing British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.
**A. Jill, 27, Skier**  
"I love the feeling of flying through the air and landing safely, but it can be scary. Sometimes I don’t feel well or the weather is bad, but I keep going. It’s hard to have a life outside of skiing because we train for ten months each year. I give up a lot of time with friends, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete together and are treated the same because it is a new sport."
**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was surprising since I had never cycled before! I earn good money as a professional cyclist, and there are many opportunities for sponsorship. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks, not my skills. So, I focus on cycling. I train for at least four hours every day, plus I do stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time it takes."
**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls because not many schools offer it. Most girls start when they are 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Coaches often change, so the women’s team struggles to stay strong. But I enjoy it and love being fit, plus there is a good social life."
**D. Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not knowing how big it was! I felt trapped in Britain and didn’t like anyone controlling me. Now, I am more careful. Each walk is different. Walking across Australia was the hardest experience for me. I walked 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters. But I set a record! I had to because my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Some men think women are more likely to fail, so they see sponsoring us as a risk."
**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men are very competitive when driving. When I do well, they often ignore me. Being a woman has its challenges. When I reach a corner, men think they must beat me, so I have had many accidents! You need to be competitive and strong. It is hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s, but they were often seen as unusual. It’s great that more women are joining racing every year. I love trying to drive perfectly."
**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need the other mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Sometimes I fall asleep at my desk! There is a lot of pressure before a race, and I push myself hard. I often ask myself why I do this. The answers are: a) I feel happier when I stay fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t push myself, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are reported in the news, most of the focus is on the men. The prize money is not as good for women either. But now we have formed an International Triathlon Women’s Commission to help improve this."

**The Day I Met Picasso**
Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 78 years old. He saw Picasso eating lunch at a restaurant in Cannes. Even from far away, Picasso was easy to recognize. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the water. But I spent a lot of time drawing and had my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.
Picasso was known to be a private person who usually stayed away from others to work. So, I was surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. I would not have asked for his signature if my friend hadn’t encouraged me. I nervously introduced myself and offered my sketchbook, and to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added some fun lines below. These lines might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.
I thanked him and started a conversation. Since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was not great either, an American woman at the table helped us talk. She called him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak. But I told Picasso that I loved art and admired his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and showed my friend what I had. He saw that Picasso was still having lunch and asked, "Is that all?" He encouraged me to go back and talk to Picasso again, saying I might not get another chance.
So, I went back to Picasso's table with my sketchbook. I didn’t ask if I could draw his portrait because I was afraid he might say no. Instead, I just stood there, took out my crayon, and started to draw. When Picasso noticed, he smiled and made funny faces, which made it hard for me to draw him. He rolled his eyes, stuck out his tongue, and made silly shapes with his hands. Even though it was difficult, I felt like he was testing my determination.
After a while, Picasso stopped being silly and sat still for me. I noticed how strong and alert he looked, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He looked much younger than his age, with bright, dark eyes that were very intense. Even though he was with friends, he seemed to be in his own world, quietly focused on his own thoughts.
When the American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing, I felt shy and said it wasn’t good enough. But Picasso insisted, so I showed him my sketch. He nodded in approval and then surprised me by saying it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In just a few seconds, he drew a bearded face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with just one lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks.
I thanked Picasso and asked if he could sign my drawing. The American woman explained that he said I already had his signature. So, he was not going to give me another one! Still, I feel very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It meant a lot to me.

**Talking Shop**
Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? This text explains how shops encourage you to spend more money.
**A. The Fresh Look**  
Supermarkets know that people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. Some even have bakeries that make the smell of fresh bread fill the store. The colors in the store, like green, can also make it feel fresh. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen food and cleaning products, is not fresh.
**B. Smart Product Placement**  
Where products are placed in a store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computers to find out which areas are most popular with shoppers. They put high-profit items in these areas. Products at eye level are more likely to be bought. Special offers in bins can attract bargain hunters. Sometimes, related items are placed together, like desserts near ice cream.
**C. Spreading Basic Items**  
Supermarkets often place low-priced items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by more expensive items on their way. Stores may also put popular products far from the entrance, hoping loyal customers will look for them and see other tempting items.
**D. Less is More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain shows fewer items on the shelves, making them seem special. Even though their clothes are mass-produced, their store design helps them sell well.
**E. Total Costs Matter**  
Shoppers care more about the total cost of their shopping than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix low-priced basic items with more expensive ones. They sometimes sell basic items at a loss to attract customers, which are called "loss leaders." They also get discounts from manufacturers by buying in large amounts.
**F. The Price Tag**  
Shoppers in chain stores often buy fewer items and pay more attention to prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This pricing strategy can also help reduce theft by staff.
**G. Lighting Matters**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores try to use natural light so customers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lighting to make fresh fruits and vegetables look better.
**H. Store Layout**  
Many chain stores use different carpet patterns to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the paths through the store, while another marks sales areas. This design encourages shoppers to explore, but some may stick to the main paths.
**I. In-Store Promotions**  
When you enter a supermarket, you often see big pictures of delicious food, which can make you hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that show ads for products while you shop. These trolleys aim to encourage impulse buying and can increase sales significantly.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**
Chris Bonnington, who is 58 years old, is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, who is 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht called Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England.
Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their adventure in a new book called *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while Chris was working on *Quest for Adventure*, he called Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail. Chris could teach Robin some climbing skills, and Robin could teach Chris how to sail. This was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed for a while and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin paddled to shore to practice climbing.
The climbing route was difficult, but Chris was impressed by how steady Robin was in tough conditions. When they reached a big drop, Chris asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. Robin had not, so Chris showed him how to do it. Robin politely asked if he could climb down using the ropes from his boat. Chris wanted him to use his legs instead of his arms. Although Chris was not happy about it, Robin safely lowered himself down.
During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a big step from their Skye adventure. Chris admired Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin asked for everyone's opinion first. Most of the time, people were too shy to give advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making.
Chris found sailing difficult and boring. He preferred the excitement of dealing with problems, but he did not like spending so many days at sea. He was not a natural sailor like Robin, who enjoyed fixing the boat. Chris sometimes felt useless and found it hard to be so close to the other crew members on a small yacht designed for four people, but they had six on board.
When they reached Greenland and it was Chris's turn to lead the climbing expedition, he felt nervous about being responsible for Robin's safety. There were times when Robin could have fallen and pulled Chris down with him. Chris did not expect how hard climbing Greenland's highest mountain, called the Cathedral, would be. Robin was not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. The first time they tried to reach the top, they climbed for 24 hours. On the way down, they were so tired that they almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin trusted Chris completely and just followed him. When it became too difficult, Chris knew they had to turn back, and Robin accepted this.
Robin was also worried about their boat and whether it would be okay in the ice. Still, he wanted to try climbing the mountain again. The only time they had a problem was on the way home. They were taking turns to keep watch on the yacht. Chris was supposed to wake up at 4 am for his shift, but Robin decided not to wake him because he thought he could handle it alone. Chris had almost fallen asleep the night before and felt that Robin did not trust him. He expressed his feelings, and Robin quickly reassured him that he was wrong to think that.
While they enjoyed their trip to Skye, they really got to know each other during the Greenland expedition. Chris discovered that Robin, despite his tough appearance, was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**
Apples have been around for a very long time, in many different colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late 20th century, we risk losing this important part of our history.
**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
People have been eating apples since ancient times. In Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. About 10,000 years ago, people left apple remains near their homes by lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these areas, ancient people even stored dried apple halves for winter. But these apples were wild crab apples, which are small and not like the apples we eat today.
**Norman Knowledge (1000 AD)**  
The Romans taught the French how to grow fruit, and this knowledge spread to Britain. They brought different types of apples, like the dessert apple called Decio, introduced by a Roman general. However, many Roman apples did not grow well in Britain, so the apples from the Normans became more popular. British monks also experimented with growing new types of apples, which led to the apples we have today.
**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
In the 13th century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a main dessert apple until the 18th century. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in markets and gave us the word 'costermonger,' which means someone who sells fruits and vegetables in the street. However, due to droughts, the Black Death, and wars, fewer apples were produced, and more were imported. This changed in the 16th century when King Henry VIII sent his fruit expert to France to learn about apple growing. He returned with many new apple types, including the famous Pippins, and started the first modern orchard in Kent.
**Settler Treasure (1750)**  
By the 17th century, apples were very popular in Britain. When settlers went to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand, they took apples and seeds with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers brought them to America. In North America, a famous apple planter was John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed.' He planted apple trees across many states and was seen as a kind man who cared for nature.
**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree in Iowa. He named the apple 'Hawkey,' and when a judge tasted it, he called it 'Delicious.' This apple became very popular worldwide.
**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She was known as 'Granny Smith' because she took care of her family's farm. In 1868, she found a small tree growing from old fruit. She moved it, and soon she had a large crop of green apples that became famous around the world. She believed that something good could come from what others thought was useless.
**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world, but most come from just a few types that are chosen for their appearance and how well they travel, not for their taste. This lack of variety is a problem, as it reduces the different types of apples we can enjoy. While some gardeners in the UK keep old apple types alive, many apples in the US have been lost. However, people are starting to want more variety. We should all work to protect the diversity of apples and other foods for everyone’s benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**
Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel. We offer trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. Our focus is on visiting new and interesting places with unique travel plans. Our brochure has over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last from 1 to 4 weeks.
**Small Groups**
We travel in small groups, usually with about 16 people. Our groups are informal and led by experienced guides. This allows you to learn more about the places we visit and connect with local people. It’s a great experience for all travelers.
**Different Ways to Travel**
We use many types of transport during our trips. You might travel by coach, local bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, or even on foot. Each trip reflects the local environment.
**Who Travels with Explore?**
Our travelers are interesting people who enjoy new experiences. Most are from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are suitable for anyone in good health and reasonably fit. Most travelers are between 25 and 55 years old. About half are couples, while the rest are solo travelers.
**Activities and Interests**
Every trip with Explore Worldwide is unique. We have divided our adventures into 8 categories based on activities and interests. Each category highlights special experiences that are part of the tour. Many factors, like unique places and local customs, make your holiday enjoyable.
**Cultural/Adventure Trips**
Most of our trips have a strong cultural focus. Some tours emphasize local cultures and historical sites. For example, you can explore Egypt, Jordan, Greece, India, and many more countries known for their rich history. Short walks of 2-4 hours to visit less-known sites are often included.
**Wildlife and Nature**
Our wildlife safaris take you to some of the best game parks in the world. In Africa, you can sometimes leave your vehicle to explore the wild. You might track gorillas in Zaire, hike with local guides in Uganda, or canoe on the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, but some offer hotel stays.
**Meeting Local People**
A special part of our adventures is meeting local ethnic groups. You might meet the Tuareg of the Sahara, the Maya of Mexico, or the Huli of Papua New Guinea. Many of these cultures are at risk, and we aim to promote understanding and respect while minimizing disturbance to their way of life.
**Easy/Moderate Hiking**
Many trips include easy walks through beautiful countryside, often staying in rented homes or hotels. You can hike from village to village, sometimes staying overnight in local homes. These trips are available in places like Spain, Greece, Morocco, and Thailand. Your main luggage is transported separately, so you only carry a small bag for the day.
**Major Treks**
We offer some challenging treks for experienced hikers. These may involve walking at high altitudes and staying with local people or camping in mountain ranges like the Himalayas and Andes. Support vehicles and porters help carry your gear.
**Wilderness Experiences**
Exploring remote wilderness areas is an exciting adventure. You can discover the beauty of the Amazon Rainforest or the deserts of the Sahara and Gobi. These trips offer a chance to experience something truly special.
**Sailing and River Journeys**
We also offer relaxing sailing trips on local boats in places like Egypt and Turkey. River journeys can last from a few hours to several days, with options for beginners and experienced paddlers. Our river trips in India, Africa, and the Amazon provide a unique view of nature and local life.

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain, known for running 10,000 meters. He visits a training camp in Kenya, which is located ten miles south of the equator. The camp is near Mount Kenya, the highest peak in the country. For three years, Richard has trained in this beautiful but quiet place, but he had never trained with Kenyan runners before. 
On his fourth trip to Kenya, he decided to change this. He ran in his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best Kenyan runners prepare for competitions. He was invited by the national team coach after he finished fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race. This was a great opportunity for him. 
Training at high altitudes helps runners produce more red blood cells, which improves their ability to carry oxygen. This is one reason why many Kenyan runners are successful. Richard's first race in Africa was also special because it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent. He finished behind 41 runners, most of whom were Kenyan, but he felt he did well.
Richard believes that Kenyan runners' success is not only because of the high altitude. They have a simple and relaxed approach to running, and they enjoy competing. He wanted to learn more about how they train. 
The national team training camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya. The camp is basic, with athletes living in shared rooms. Their daily schedule includes three workouts: a morning run, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the afternoon. They start their day at six in the morning. The coach reminds them to take it easy during the morning run because they have a tough day ahead. They run about 40 kilometers each day, except on Sundays when they only run 20 kilometers.
Life at the camp is simple. They wash their faces and brush their teeth before breakfast, which includes tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar, with dishes like ugali (a maize dish), stew, and vegetables. After running, they often go to bathe in streams from Mount Kenya's glaciers.
By the end of his stay, Richard understood more about why Kenyan runners are so successful. It is not just about genetics or altitude; it is also about their simple lifestyle, hard training, and passion for running. These factors may be the real reasons behind Kenya's success in long-distance running.

**The Challenges of Mass Marketing**
Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This problem started in early 1989, before the recession really hit. The truth is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large groups of people and big media, but as more brands and media options appear, the target audiences have become smaller and more specific. Even big brand campaigns should focus on smaller groups, but they usually do not.
Think about your own shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands. You might buy a few well-known brands, but you will not buy many different brands in a year. For example, you might only buy around 400 different brands in a year, even though there are over 32,500 brands advertised.
If we look at the 9,500 brands that are often advertised, the average person only buys about 400 of them, which is only 4 percent. This means that a lot of advertising is not effective. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy. Most people find that only about 1 in 16 ads (6 percent) are for brands they are interested in. This means that 94 percent of the ads are not useful for them.
Many people believe they are not influenced by advertising, but that is not true. Most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. There is always some waste in advertising because not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. However, advertising can still be effective. It needs to reach many people to find the few who will respond, as advertisers cannot know in advance who will be interested.
Even the best-targeted ads do not get a 100 percent response. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every customer they talk to. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use mass media at all.
For any advertising campaign, getting just 2 percent of the adult population to become new customers is considered a success. For example, the top-selling soap powder brands would be very happy with one million new customers. So, while mass media can be a good way to reach people, advertising needs to be more focused to be successful again.

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Visits a Green Home**
Charles Clover explores one of the most environmentally-friendly homes in Britain, located in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This area has some interesting surprises. First, there is Southwell Minster, a little-known ancient cathedral famous for its carvings of 'green' men made by medieval craftsmen. Second, there is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale, which is known as the greenest home in Britain.
The Vales use rainwater for drinking and washing, recycle their sewage into compost for their garden, and heat their home using waste heat from their electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the orange brick of the town's older buildings and was approved by planners even though it is in a conservation area.
When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you hear no sound because the house is very well insulated. It has special windows that keep noise out. Inside, it is very quiet and calm. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it goes into the house. Robert shows how the house has clever ventilation systems to keep the air fresh.
The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have cared about the environment for many years. They wrote a book about green architecture in the 1970s called *The Autonomous House*. They wanted to create a home that does not produce carbon dioxide and decided to use only rainwater. They built special toilets that compost waste, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep the drinking water clean. They filter the water before using it and do not have a dishwasher because they believe using strong detergents is wrong. 
Robert says, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is better for the environment without living in darkness." The only old-fashioned part of the house is the hall, which has a fireplace and a staircase that goes up to the roof. The Vales do not pay for water, and last winter, their house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use.
Soon, they will install solar panels in the garden, which will help the house generate its own electricity. The house will still use some electricity from the mains for cooking and appliances, but it will produce more electricity than it needs. One day, it might even charge an electric car. The only heating in the house is a small wood-burning stove, which they only use on very cold days. 
When Charles visited in February, Robert said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than usual for living areas, but Robert felt comfortable because there were no drafts and everything felt warm to the touch. He explained that people in the past were comfortable at lower temperatures because of their clothing. 
The secret of the house is that it is simple and low-tech, which means there are fewer things that can break. Most materials were bought from local suppliers and installed by local workers, making the house affordable to build. It cost the same as low-cost rental housing. However, big building companies do not want to adopt this idea.

**The Camera Never Lies**
Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a rational man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real proof that these tiny creatures existed. He published these photos with an article, saying that fairies were wonderful supernatural beings. 
However, in 1939, the two women who took the photos admitted that they were fake. They had cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos looked beautiful, but the simple trick showed that photography can be misleading. 
People often say that the camera never lies, but it can. Today, we have computer programs that let us change our digital images. It is a myth that photography was ever completely honest. From the beginning, when cameras started to capture reality, that reality was being changed.

**Blacksmiths**
Throughout history, iron has fascinated people, and blacksmiths, who work with iron, have been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also considered artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. The elegant metalwork in French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings was also made by talented blacksmiths. 
However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased because heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern architects rarely used beautiful wrought-iron designs. In the last 10 years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and more creative interior design. Still, much of the work looks similar, with many manufacturers calling their products "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find trendy design stores filled with rusty candlesticks and other similar items.
Fortunately, there are new events to promote the blacksmith's craft. One of these is an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), which opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, believes we might be starting a new "Iron Age" because both the public and blacksmiths are more open to new ideas. 
Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, twist, and weld it more easily. Dawson says, "These artists now have a material that lets them express themselves." About 250 pieces are on display, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but a part of each sale will help promote good ironwork.
Dawson has created an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He explains, "My style comes from letting steel bend and flow into shape when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space." Many artists love working with iron. Unlike other metals, iron and steel are tough and challenging to work with. Susan May, a jeweler, says, "It's magical because it's soft when hot, but when it cools, it becomes hard and unmovable."
Ann Catrin Evans makes door knockers and handles from mild steel, inspired by the dark castles seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, and another like a Celtic cross. She says, "I love that steel is cold and hard, and it feels like it will last forever." No other metal gives people as much visual pleasure or a sense of security. It seems likely that iron will continue to be used for decoration for many years to come, as long as we don’t have to see any more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Gave Up Smoking**
I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my coworkers was very angry. She asked, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was strange for me too. 
I stopped smoking two months and three weeks ago. I didn’t plan to quit, and I didn’t really want to. I felt pressure from people who are against smoking, and I still do. I also had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I got over colds faster than my friends who tried to live healthier. 
That Thursday afternoon, I went to a stop-smoking session in Birmingham to write an article about it. I said, "I won’t try to stop smoking; I’m just here to write." I thought it was fair because I enjoyed smoking. The counselor seemed to understand me. We could smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. 
I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. The messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. Just like smoking had become a challenge, the idea of stopping began to feel good. I started to feel strong about the possibility of not being a smoker. 
It was easier than I thought. The cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it wasn’t a problem at all. I was worried I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without smoking, but I did fine. 
Surprisingly, the hardest part was doing things at home on weekend mornings. I realized that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was something to do. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to, like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a break at the theater. These are all moments when I would have smoked before.

**Dorothy Hodgkin: A Scientist Worth Knowing**
Dorothy Hodgkin was the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but many people in Britain do not know her name. For the past four years, I have been asking friends if they know about her. If they respond with excitement and say, "Isn't there already a biography?" they pass my test. 
Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? She won a Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964 for her work on important substances like penicillin and vitamin B12. She was a remarkable person and her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like the growth of women's education and the global sharing of scientific knowledge.
When I started my research, I wanted to read biographies of scientists. A friend suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a close friend of Hodgkin and also won Nobel Prizes. I went to a local bookshop but found no biographies of Pauling. I was surprised because he was a very important chemist. This made me realize that many people do not find scientists interesting enough to read about.
Some scientists believe that their lives are not exciting. Peter Medawar, a Nobel Prize winner, once said that the lives of scientists are often boring. If scientists think this way, it is not surprising that publishers and bookstores feel the same. Many biographies focus only on famous scientists, while the lives of other scientists are often ignored.
It is not true that scientists have less interesting lives than artists, writers, or politicians. Some scientists avoid talking about their personal lives because they do not want to seem like they are promoting themselves. This can make science seem less inviting to young people and create misunderstandings about what scientists do.
Fortunately, things are changing. More scientists are appearing in public in different ways. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives out awards on TV, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car commercials. These activities help people see scientists as real people, not just researchers.
The way scientific biographies are written is also changing. In the past, they were often boring and focused only on work. But now, books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?" show that scientists can have interesting lives outside of their research. Even famous scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein are now shown with their personal struggles.
Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her work and also raised three children while being married to a husband who traveled a lot for his job. Her personal life is not the main focus of her work, but it shows how she balanced different parts of her life. 
Hodgkin's passion for science was a big part of her life, and it is important for any scientist to have this passion. The challenge for biographers is to share this passion in a way that readers can understand. Learning about science can be as challenging as reading Shakespeare or learning a new language, but it is possible with effort.
It is sad that many educated people do not know about important scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, even though they would feel embarrassed if they did not recognize a famous writer or artist. We should celebrate the contributions of scientists and learn from their lives.

**Margaret and Her Water Finding Skills**
Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a "sixth sense." She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Many farmers need her help because their wells have dried up. Margaret and her husband run a well-drilling business that uses machines like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, she only needs her hazel stick. They have a success rate of over 90%.
This ability to find water, minerals, and lost items underground is called dowsing. There are many ideas about how it works, from physical reasons like magnetism to spiritual beliefs. One popular idea is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Some dowsers believe they can feel these vibrations, while others think they can smell water.
In recent years, Margaret has been very busy because of droughts. Many of her customers are farmers with dry wells. She says, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other customers include people with holiday homes who do not want to pay for long water pipes, and developers building golf courses.
Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She explains, "You can't drill where there is a risk of waste getting into the water." The water she finds is usually in safe places, but she has to be careful because some areas have high mineral content, like iron.
Electricity is also needed to pump the water, so it is best if the well is close to power sources. Once she considers all these factors, she starts looking for water. For large areas like golf courses, she first studies a map and uses a pendulum. She holds the pendulum over the map, and it swings when she is above a water source.
After checking the map, Margaret walks over the fields with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation. She then uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill. She holds the two forks of the stick and pulls them slightly apart. If the stick rises, it means water is below. It is very important to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If they disagree on the spot, she and her husband will keep looking until they agree.
Margaret is not alone in her work; many people are interested in this unusual skill. She describes it as an "intuitive perception of the environment." This special ability helps her family continue their well-drilling business year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**
Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It could be fun to try something different! We helped four people do this. Here’s what happened.
**Amanda's Story**
Amanda is 23 years old and a mother of two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy restaurant in London. 
Amanda had never been in a place like that before. It was dark, loud, and full of people. She felt nervous and thought it would be hard to manage. Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was even more challenging! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry drinks on a tray. Other waitresses made it look easy, but when Amanda tried, the drinks fell and spilled everywhere. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and said it happens to everyone.
When the restaurant opened at 11:30 am, there was already a line of customers. Amanda worried about remembering their orders, but luckily, everything was done with computers. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and the loud music was hard to handle. She often had to ask customers to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was very tired and wanted to relax her feet in hot water. One waitress told her it was a "quiet" day, and Amanda was shocked at how tiring waitressing was. She thought it was an easy job, but it actually requires a lot of energy and a friendly attitude. Amanda realized she could not handle the busy Saturday nights. She was also disappointed with the tips she received. In the end, she was happy to return to her children, as being a mother felt easier after her day as a waitress.
**Cindy's Story**
Cindy is 30 years old and felt nervous about being a mother for a day, but she was also excited. She knew Amanda's daughters could be cheeky, but she thought she could manage. 
When Amanda left for the restaurant, Cindy had to get the two girls ready for the day. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, she thought she would have some quiet time. But she was wrong! Amanda had left a note reminding her to clean the house and do the laundry. 
At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, went shopping, and then took her home for lunch. When she brought Sophie home from school, things got wild. The girls turned the couch into a trampoline and screamed loudly while playing. Cindy thought they would tire out, but they had more energy than she expected! After a lot of effort, she finally got them to bed by 8 pm, but then the fun continued. The girls kept asking for water, trying to get out of bed to watch TV. Cindy realized it was tiring to take care of two small children. She had no time for herself, and the responsibility felt heavy. Still, she enjoyed the day.
**Rosemary's Story**
Rosemary is 42 and runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, who is 30 and a primary school teacher. 
On the farm, Rosemary wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 am felt great! She worried about how to dress for school. At assembly, she hoped no one noticed her as she stood in front of about 400 students. 
In class, the children worked in small groups, which was different from Rosemary's school days. She helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, she was tired but only had five minutes to eat. There was a lot to do before the next classes. She attended a meeting and helped with sports trials. After lunch, she enjoyed a silent reading lesson and then a French lesson, where the children practiced speaking with her. Finally, they had Physical Education, and by then, Rosemary was very tired, but the children were full of energy. Speaking in front of the class was the hardest part for her. Even though teachers have more holidays, Rosemary decided she prefers farming.
**Hilary's Story**
Hilary is 30 and arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find that Rosemary had been working for three hours already! Rosemary's farm has many animals, including cows and sheep. 
Hilary spent the morning in the ice-cream shop, filling containers with milk and making ice cream. She had to stop herself from tasting everything! At lunchtime, she checked on the sheep and helped a fallen ewe. If sheep are not checked daily, they can die. After feeding the calves, Hilary started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year! 
Hilary felt lonely and missed being around children because animals do not talk back. The hardest part of farming is that there is no time off. The cows need to be milked twice a day, making it hard to plan vacations. Farming may seem romantic, but the reality is very different. The income can be unstable, and Hilary would not want to depend on the weather.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas. It is interesting that many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of parents who did not play music, is now 30 years old and is a unique trumpet player in the world. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by old composers and new pieces. When you meet him, he looks young and has a friendly manner, just like the sound of the trumpet.
Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls. A television program was made about his work and life, filmed in London and Sweden. Hakan was born near Malmo, Sweden. His music career started when he was eight years old and received a trumpet as a Christmas gift from his father. His father liked Louis Armstrong's music and wanted to give his son a real trumpet, not a toy. The gift was a success, and Hakan loved playing.
His mother found a trumpet player from the Malmo Symphony Orchestra to give him lessons. Bo Nilsson, the teacher, saw Hakan's natural talent. Hakan is grateful to have had such a passionate teacher. He explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to make a perfect one. Each mouthpiece is different, and he believes it is important to understand these differences and work with them.
From the beginning, Hakan had a special sound that people could recognize. Unlike another famous trumpet player, John Wallace, who played in orchestras, Hakan always wanted to be a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter, Maurice Andre, and bought all his records. His parents supported his dream of becoming a trumpet player.
At 15, Hakan needed to decide where to study. His teacher thought America was too far, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud told him that playing in an orchestra was not as exciting as being a soloist. Hakan knew he played better than many of his peers, but it was only when he entered a competition at 17 that he realized he had a special ability to connect with people through music.
Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hakan learned the first round pieces and made it to the second round. He was lucky to know most of the pieces for that round too. However, in the final round, he faced a concerto that scared him. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed performing and realized that people listened to him, even if he felt he played poorly.
Hakan is realistic about his talent and career, but he does not want to analyze what makes his communication special. He believes that trying to explain it might ruin it. The power of music is that it can always touch people's hearts.

**New In Paperback**
A. The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up country of Efica, is a unique tale about power, history, and humor. The author has skillfully created a world with its own history and traditions. The book is also funny and shows the author's special view of life, combined with deep understanding of people. It is a challenging but rewarding read.
B. Harriet is a confident middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not meet Sheila, a working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about what happened. Leo, who was a good student and had never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe, who is healing physically, becomes quiet and withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by what happened to her son, and taking care of him becomes her main focus. Sheila feels guilty and asks to meet Harriet, which leads to an unexpected friendship. The author is great at showing how people react to difficult situations in their lives and captures a mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her child.
C. This book, which was nominated for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated islands in the Scottish Orkney and its people over a long, quiet history. The story is set against important moments in Scottish history, imagined through the daydreams of a young boy named Throfinn Ragnarson. He suddenly disappears in the story but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.
D. After his recent big success, the author has written a sequel that continues the gentle humor and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies and has a lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's way of living is still a mix of vanity, charm, and a bit of kindness, and Rosie helps her in her amusing interactions with friends and suitors. By the end of the book, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is now in the spotlight. The author skillfully shows the sadness that lies beneath the everyday moments of life and highlights the randomness of events.
E. Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to tell the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences as they prepare to return home, feeling more alive after their time at sea. The author uses striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which can be both confusing and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**
Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their different jobs: the good parts, the bad parts, and what a typical workday is like.
**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  
**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and get to work by 8 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I do surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can take all day. Sometimes, I work for ten hours without eating or taking a break. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. I don’t feel stressed while I’m operating, but I do worry about what I will do the next day. Brain surgery is usually a last option for patients, but when it works, it feels amazing. From 10 am to 1 pm, I see patients to explain their operations. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to them. If they get upset, I try to comfort them, but I often feel rushed. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call, and I always carry my beeper. When I’m on holiday, I worry about my patients for the first few days, and I often dream about operating. I find it hard to relax."
**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  
**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our work and any problems. I work in a team with three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. My job is mostly about production, with some design work. I get a brief from the client about what they want. I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. If they like them, we work on budgets and I hire photographers and illustrators. I also work with printers to make sure everything is done on time. I spend a lot of time managing people and need to communicate well. When I get home, it’s usually between 7:30 pm and 8:30 pm, and sometimes later. I find it hard to relax after a busy day."
**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  
**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7 am, but on some days, I get up between 4:30 am and 5 am for long flights. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I need to eat well and exercise. I have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People often ask me for restaurant or shop recommendations, so I need to know the area well. Most jobs are pre-booked, which helps me plan my routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude. But most are nice, and I have good relationships with my regular clients. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I have to be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."
**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  
**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each house. At around 11 am, we take a break and go to a local café for breakfast. In summer, I might work until 10 pm, and in winter until 4:30 pm. I have my office at home, so when I return, I check messages and calls. If someone wants a new garden, I usually meet them in the evening. We like to use old materials to make gardens look historic. It’s very satisfying to see a garden we created bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone. I sleep well because my job is very physical, and I am always tired at the end of the day."
**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  
**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the work site by 8:30 am. I am an assistant engineer, helping to build bridges and a wall to keep cars safe. I check that the workers are following the schedule and safety rules. I help solve any problems that come up. The workers start at 6 am, so my first job is to find out what happened since I left the night before. I usually have paperwork to review or design questions to answer. I take a half-hour lunch break between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat while I work. Since I check the workers' progress, I need to keep a good relationship with them. I leave the site around 6 pm and am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**
**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I manage programs for our credit card users. My job includes starting and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in Europe. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then check my emails.
