Many modern fishing methods use large nets that can trap dolphins. In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on beaches in France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died because they were caught in these nets.
Dolphins can also store harmful substances in their bodies. For example, pesticides can build up in dolphins because they are fat-soluble. This means that when female dolphins produce milk, it can contain high levels of these poisons, which can harm their young. There is already one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s poisoned milk.
Another serious threat to dolphins is noise pollution caused by humans. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their environment. In the ocean, noise travels much better than in the air. This noise from ships and oil wells may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**GETTING FIT**
Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you feel balanced, especially when life feels chaotic. You might think this is just another article about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to.
Exercise helps improve your muscles and can change your body shape quickly. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you stand and sit better. It can also prevent injuries by fixing muscle imbalances. Exercise can quickly improve areas like your thighs, stomach, and arms. It is good for your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.
You may have heard many reasons to exercise before, but here are some new ones: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can help you sleep better. It also helps manage stress and can relieve some health problems. 
If you are not convinced yet, just remember that exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or using weights. However, be careful not to push yourself too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. If you are unsure about what is best for you, talk to your doctor.
Good posture is also important. If you have bad posture, it can make you look and feel less energetic. To improve your posture, imagine that a balloon is pulling the top of your head up. This can help you breathe better and make your body look slimmer.
Stretching is another important part of exercise. It helps you move better and keeps your muscles from getting hurt. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. 
A good exercise routine should include a warm-up, stretching, a workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**
What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman stay away from home for many months? They are looking for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it can be hard to find producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost non-stop rain. This has caused some unexpected problems. Newman said they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety.
Their teamwork has created some of the best wildlife films on TV, like their popular film about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time following the shy jackal. This is common for film-makers who travel the world to film exotic wildlife since television began.
I talked to Newman about their partnership while he was having a rare meeting with other people at a safari lodge. He said, "We do have occasional arguments, but we get over them quickly." Neither of them sees themselves as the leader. They get along well because they both understand animals in a similar way.
When they travel, they set up their tents each night. But now, they are working from a fixed camp. They leave at 5 a.m. each morning, so they make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask. Their daily meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. Newman said, "It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can be a bit stressful."
Life can be tough, but being in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a family of lions. One lioness would often go off alone, but when she returned, she would greet all the other lions, and eventually, she would greet their car too.
Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they started working together to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months in one location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval.
Newman said, "Amanda and I had a good working relationship from the start because we shared the same ideas and vision. We want to create a film that captures the true spirit of the place and the animals, and that touches people's hearts. I believe if you can make people feel something, it is better than just making them think."

**The Netball Captain**
In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I was surprised to hear about her training place. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus on my movements and my feet, so I don’t notice much else. I might see cars slow down a little, but that’s it."
Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to be very fit for the games. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have support from home, which is special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in our country. There will be more pressure because we are playing at home. People expect us to start the tournament with a good game."
Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra believes they have always won against them, but it will still be exciting to play because Barbados has talented players. The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra knows the Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself every day. There is no rest between games like in a series. In the Championships, you only have one chance, so you must be ready."
In the fifteen years Kendra has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive now. "You don’t train hard to lose," Kendra said. But after the game, everyone is friendly. 
Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. "We must think and train like world-class players," Kendra explained. As captain, she believes it is important to have a strong mindset and to lead by example. "I support and encourage my team."
Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes, knowing her loyal supporters are with her.

**In Hot Water**
Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemicals in the sea. Rachel works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle, like a car, and dives three kilometers down into the ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
Inside the vehicle, there is very little space. Rachel says, "I can reach out and touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside." A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.
If there is a problem and they need to get to the surface quickly, they can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out, which goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it would not be a nice trip.
Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She got in with an instructor who explained what to do in an emergency, even if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands, where there are many underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off equipment to study a project that would make a hole 150 meters through a volcano.
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.' This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where hot water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out at a speed of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."
The only time Rachel felt scared was during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when suddenly there was a loud explosion. She thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, but when nothing happened, they felt incredible relief—they were still alive!
Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels amazed. She thinks, "Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has ever seen this." Rachel studied the black smokers for three years for her Ph.D. When she finally saw them in real life, it was an amazing feeling.

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. Studies show that people make judgments about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, how fast or slow we talk, our voice volume and tone, and the words we use.
Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard to get her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing, but she didn’t want to be late because she believes it is important to be on time. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who works at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn’t take the time to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says that people who care about their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. Many people think that what is inside matters most, but in an interview, you should try to present yourself well.
Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a big accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the job but did not get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed her work was good and that her clothes should not matter.
Body language and gestures also affect how an interviewer sees a candidate. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our words and facial expressions send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. So, it is important that your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.
It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion and did so well in her interview that she was offered the job right away. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. The boss realized she would accept the offer, so he gave her a lower salary than she wanted. Sheila believes she could have asked for more money if she had controlled her excitement.
Finally, what you say and how you say it can help you succeed in an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can tell you about the company’s work. Mentioning something that interests you during the interview can show your interest in the company.
Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and key points."

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He worked in the City for 14 years, but he felt it became boring and no one was enjoying their work anymore. He did not plan to leave his job yet, but he was suddenly made redundant. He did not get a lot of money when he left, but it was enough to start his farm. His big break came when he met the head chef of a well-known hotel restaurant. By supplying meat to them, he became more popular, and now he also sells meat online. Matt is happy to be out of the office, but he still works long hours, about 80 to 90 a week, and he is still selling a product.
**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby and found it much more exciting than his job. When he was made redundant, he decided to become an artist. A career counselor helped him, and he told the counselor that he did not want to go back to his old job. This surprised the counselor because most people in their forties need to find work quickly for money. Ron and his wife moved to the north of England, where they did not know anyone. They left their friends behind, but they have been lucky because their friends still visit them.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. She enjoyed being a lawyer and earned a lot of money, but the hours were very long. She did not want to become a senior partner and work even more, so she decided to leave. Many people thought she would get bored, but that has not happened. She keeps busy with deadlines for her fashion business, which helps her stay organized. Katherine feels happier and less stressed now, but she misses talking to colleagues. She loves being responsible for her own work. If she does a bad job, she knows she is the one to blame, and that makes her care more about her work.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance at 22, but he did not find it rewarding. In 1989, he almost lost his job, so he decided to resign and travel for a year. During that year, he thought about what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited many gyms and talked to their owners about starting a business. Paul knew he needed qualifications to change careers, so he took courses in massage. Then he got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He has no regrets about his decision. He feels more in control of his life now and enjoys having peace of mind.

**Dedicated to Their Sports**
Four young sports stars talk about their lives.
**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always loved sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest moment was when I competed for my country in the youth team and won a medal. Unfortunately, it did not get much attention in the media, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun there because the facilities are great and the nightlife is exciting. However, I have to be very disciplined. If my friends invite me out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but being dedicated is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics - that would be amazing.
**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn. To succeed, I have to avoid late-night parties. I don’t mind this too much, but I love sleeping in, which I often have to give up. However, it is worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice trip. Winning the championship also allowed me to present a surfing series on TV, so now I am a bit of a celebrity.
**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When I am on a boat with my friends, we have a lot of fun. We are traditional and celebrate our wins in style. Some people say we act a bit childish, but we don’t look for media attention. Sometimes, reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I spend eight months a year away, so it is nice to come back and hang out with my friends who do different things. You can’t focus on sports all the time; it’s not healthy. I am known in sailing, but I am not recognized much in public, which I like. I get nice letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I reply to every one, even if it takes time.
**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to walk onto the court and feel the crowd cheering for me. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with fans crowding around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I am out shopping, but it has some downsides. My last girlfriend didn’t like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but sacrifices are part of any sport; you have to be serious and professional. I am focused on my game now and will catch up on other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.

**Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for some parents. One mother says, "It feels like a battle. They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic book. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all of this, and when I give in, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave the house. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that they are missing out on learning how to make choices. I just can’t win."
Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. More than £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed at children, mostly on television. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a big part of this advertising. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things. Arguments about how bad sugar is for teeth are not convincing when they see fun and exciting ads on TV.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertising and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she tries to be patient when talking about food with her children, but she still feels unsure about how to handle their requests. "My son pays attention to ads, but he is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very few arguments in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."
Parents also admit they are not always consistent with their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We don’t buy him the sweets he wants because we say they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on my mood. If I’m feeling good, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce the conflict between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Even if parents spend less money because their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands might attract more customers.

**Five-Star Luxury with Modern Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It was created by changing four large old houses and took almost two years to complete. The hotel has the latest technology to help both the staff and the guests.
General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know the guests' names. For more details about what guests like, he uses a computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost £250,000 to set up, but MacCann believes it will be worth it over time. He is happy with how well it works. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them when they come back.
Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The Merrion has a high-tech system that lets guests change the temperature in their rooms. They can adjust it by three degrees around the normal 18°C. The front desk can also change the temperature anywhere from 14°C to 25°C.
Business guests will find the technology in their rooms very useful. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the hotel’s business will come from this group. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that can also copy and print, and a video-conferencing system. The hotel has prepared for future technology changes by adding extra cables. They rent televisions so they can easily replace them with newer models when needed.
Even with all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 large and well-furnished bedrooms that are cozy and inviting. There is also a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.
The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This change allows him to create a modern kitchen and improve parking for guests. The hotel benefits from having a great restaurant without taking financial risks. With good technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

**Where I Get My Energy**
Emma Marsden asked six women how they find energy in their lives.
A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get my energy from excitement. I need challenges and learning new things. Right now, I am learning flamenco dancing, which is very energizing. If I am bored, I feel tired. Doing something meaningful, even small things, gives me energy."
B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. If you like what you do, it doesn’t feel hard, even if you are tired. I need enough sleep to feel good. When I only get six hours, I feel a bit low. Exercise helps me feel energetic, but I have to find the energy to do it! I go to a yoga class once a week and try to work out at home. After exercising, I feel much better. I often feel tired in the afternoon, so I think it’s good to eat something then."
C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don’t eat very healthily for energy; I think it comes from being enthusiastic and positive. I dislike negative people. I believe we should enjoy life and set goals. I love my job and the last two years have been exciting. I work with many lively young people, which keeps me energized. I enjoy taking photos, even if I’m not the best at it. I also write words for fun songs when I travel."
D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in what I do, both at work and with my family. Being positive helps a lot. I love working with kids because they are full of energy. Smiling at others can make you feel good. I try to eat healthily and don’t smoke or drink, but I don’t have a strict exercise plan. I get my energy from playing with kids."
E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "I love creating gardens from empty land. I once turned a concrete area into a garden by breaking the concrete and adding soil. This gives me more energy than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing also motivates me. I enjoy exploring nature, even if it’s on private land. It feels fun and childlike."
F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I think it’s important to care about what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don’t want to do makes me tired. I used to be part of many committees, but I didn’t like the time they took. You have limited energy, so focus on what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron skates were made in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For the rich people in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as elegant, but at the 1924 Winter Olympics, an 11-year-old girl named Sonja Henie showed a more athletic style, which made skating very popular.
Today, skating combines art and sport. It is both beautiful and physically challenging. For beginners, balance and control are very important. You can only go faster as you get better. The way you position your body helps with balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and your knees relaxed. Your body should lean a little forward.
Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. When you push with your back foot, make a small movement with the other foot. It’s not too hard! If you practice this for a while, you can slowly make bigger movements as you get better.
Learning how to fall is one of the first things a skater should know. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, try to stay relaxed. This helps reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, and then stand up.
Once you feel confident on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and skating in pairs. It is best to start with figure skating and then learn basic freestyle. Most ice rinks have teachers who can help you learn the basic moves, turns, jumps, and spins.
If you watch good skaters, you will see how relaxed and smooth they are. To skate well, you should practice exercises regularly. It can be dangerous to skate when your body is stiff, so warm-up exercises are important. Focus on your legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.
Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also makes your heart and lungs stronger and helps your body become healthier. When combined with swimming or jogging, skating is a great way to stay fit.

**Trills and Bills**
Seeing a talented child win a medal can make anyone cry with joy. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about the good and bad parts of their lives.
A. **Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "Right now, my training is very hard. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I take it one day at a time. When I feel really tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can’t take too many days off because it makes your body stiff."
B. **Annika's Mother**  
"From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I’ve seen some parents push their kids, but that doesn’t work. To perform at Annika’s level takes a lot of time and energy, and she has to want it herself. People often say we, as parents, have given up a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and gained confidence."
C. **Sarah Stokes, 12**  
Sarah started show-jumping at age 10 and has won the British National Championship. "It’s good that my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love it! Even if my parents weren’t there, I would still do it because I am determined. I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team this year, and my big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."
D. **Sarah's Mother**  
"From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age 1, I knew she had a passion. When she was 5, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the horse box. Sarah is very organized and is happiest when she is on a horse. Watching her succeed at something she loves is amazing."
E. **Jane McShane, 10**  
Jane is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t concentrate as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about being proud; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like to feel embarrassed."
F. **Jane's Mother**  
"Jane played her first chess game when she was 5. My father wanted to see if she liked it. I was bored when he tried to teach me, but Jane loved it right away. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves and was beating adults by age 6. I’m happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I would support her. I don’t want to hold her back because she is so talented. If she has this gift, I want her to reach her full potential."

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, he is Britain's tallest man at 228 cm.
Every ten years, the average height of people in Europe increases by one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how we were as cavemen. We are starting to lose the effects of many years of poor diet. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again, the people who lived on Earth 40,000 years ago."
For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started, and this changed everything. Farmers took over many green areas, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories we eat today. This poor diet has harmed our health. 
In Ohio, scientists found that when they started to grow corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sick and underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, which was thought to be good, actually caused health problems. However, farming spread because one piece of land could feed ten times more people than hunting could.
Today, many people are still poorly nourished, but this is slowly changing in wealthier countries. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are becoming more like our ancestors' diets. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a good trend, but it has its own problems. 
Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Also, legroom in planes and trains seems to be getting smaller, and clothing companies have to change their sizes often. The question is: how tall can we get? 
Some scientists think we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, there is a twist. While people may be growing taller because of better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were a bit rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even when we eat well. As the planet continues to warm, we might shrink even more. So, our growth could be affected by global warming.

**Studio Audiences**
What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of making television, but many people do not understand them. When we watch game shows, we see the audience getting excited and wonder, "Who are these people?"
Some people think that studio audiences are not very important. I have heard that even people who work in television do not think highly of them. One cameraman even said they are treated "like cattle." I used to think that studio audiences were just made up of silly people wanting a moment of fame. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract different types of people for different programs.
Many of us who watch television at home do not understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio just to watch what they can see at home? One reason is that people hope to be on television for a moment. I did not believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said she came for a chance to appear on TV. Another reason is that people are curious to see how a show is made. But the most common reason I heard was, "A friend gave me a ticket."
Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone holds up cards that say "APPLAUD" or "LAUGH," and you do what the card says. This is true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, "We always assume a show will be good enough not to need these signs."
Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting." Charlotte liked being part of live television. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." What I missed was seeing the live actors. I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were so far away that I ended up watching the show on a monitor.
Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch television, but that is not what matters. For most people in the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favorite Places**
**Bruce**  
I don’t like wild landscapes. I prefer places with people. When I travel, I enjoy lovely villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling helped me relax from school. I loved exploring the hills, valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, the landscape felt familiar but also different. I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my diary. This was my first try at travel writing, which I later became known for.
**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it doesn’t cost much more than regular tickets. The views are not amazing. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we see people doing everyday things, like making tea or folding a chair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train, looking into their homes. I like the simple landscape of fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look closer and find something new.
**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors enjoy the beauty of the sea. This coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast that you can combine with trips into beautiful valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in a simple self-catering place with a family in the village of Southole.
**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland that is great for hiking. There are not many people living there or visiting. It is a quiet and remote area, and I like the feeling of space. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and I visit every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. I feel sad that he is growing up in a city.
**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but when I was twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a magical, quiet, romantic house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**
We are a family that loves animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she found a beautiful pine snake. She asked, "Can we keep him?" I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank ready for animals like this, so we could look at it and learn more from our natural history book.
I got home late and quickly started boiling some water. Suddenly, I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their bedroom. The problem was with Domino, our cat, and Bianca, the white mouse I got for Mother's Day. Domino had caught the mouse and was running around the room, trying to escape with it. 
In the chaos, I tripped and fell on the floor. I saw the snake escaping from the table and slithering across the floor. The room was full of kids, the cat, and the mouse, all jumping and screaming. The dog was barking loudly, and my pot boiled over in the kitchen. I quickly turned off the gas and went back to help.
I managed to grab Domino by the tail and saved the little mouse from his mouth. The mouse was wet but unharmed. This same mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived a long life.
Feeling good about saving the mouse, I looked at the snake. It seemed strong and wild. I sat on the floor, trying to calm it down. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body. I carefully lifted the snake and walked to the end of the garden. I wanted to let it go near a tree.
When I finally let go of the snake's head, I was scared it would bite me. Instead, it slid over my shoulders like a colorful scarf. We stood there in the evening light, with my four children, me, and the snake. My oldest son, DJ, broke the silence and said, "Mum, you are warm, and the shed is not."
I asked the kids to help me encourage the snake to move. Slowly, it started to go up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of its tail vanished, my three-year-old son Clay sighed and said, "Wow, that was one big snake!"

**Drop Me a Line!**
In our fast world of phones and computers, writing letters is at risk of disappearing. But for me, receiving a letter is special and cannot be replaced by other ways of communication. There is excitement when a letter arrives, joy in seeing who it is from, and happiness in reading what it says.
I have been writing letters for a long time. It started with little notes to my mother. She always made me write thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back. My father sometimes wrote long, funny letters, which I loved. Most of the letters were about everyday life with my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters more.
I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we kept in touch by writing. Writing letters helped our relationships because I could express my feelings better in writing than by talking. I enjoy letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it’s even better to get a lot of news in a letter! I love receiving letters from different places, like Sri Lanka, Australia, and Vancouver. I also have a friend in France. We started talking in a restaurant while on holiday, and I asked for her address. If she hadn’t replied, we would have missed out on a great friendship. Now, we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French with her since she doesn’t speak English. We have visited each other’s homes.
My best letter-writing experience was this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. People were surprised that our friendship lasted so long, and the local newspaper even wrote about it!
I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make them write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did for my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, thanks to my penfriend. I encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**
Many ancient pictures carved into rocks at a famous tourist site in France are being damaged. Scientists worry that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being harmed so quickly that they may not last for future generations. 
The mountain is thought to have been a place for prayer and worship, and it has drawings that are about 4,000 years old. These drawings show cows with horns, fields, and different gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti. 
Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues like this, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and makes the artwork less clear. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. He also mentions that when people cannot take a good photograph, they rub the drawings to make them look clearer. 
Other researchers have noticed that some people bring long sticks with sharp ends to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. 
Henry de Lumley, the director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He says that if this does not happen, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be lost. 
Clottes disagrees with this idea. He says, "Henry de Lumley's plan is very strict, and while it may work, it will also upset local people." He reminds us that the site was declared a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do everything we can to protect it. 
David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says, "Henry de Lumley's idea is not perfect. Our department believes that people should be able to see the site, but it is hard to stop visitors from causing damage because the area is so large. I would like everyone to see it, but we do not have enough money to hire enough guards. We may need to think about charging a fee since there is no government funding." 
In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has also studied the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach, the damage will increase. She believes the best solution is to block off the area and provide guides. "We cannot say the plan cannot happen because there is no money," she says. "That is not good enough. Money must be found because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we do not act, we will be responsible for losing these drawings for future generations."

**Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "It feels like a battle. They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic book. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and when I give in, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave the house. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry they are missing out on learning how to make choices. I just can’t win."
Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed at children, mostly on TV. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a big part of this advertising. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things, especially when they see fun and persuasive ads. 
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is important for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertising and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb explains, "The goal of advertising is to convince people to buy products. Even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to accept and which to refuse. One mother says she tries to be patient when talking about food with her children, but she still feels unsure about how to handle their requests. "My son notices ads, but he is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have less conflict in the supermarket because my children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."
Parents also admit they are not always consistent with their children’s requests. Mike, who has a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We don’t buy him sweets because we say they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy treats, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on my mood. If I’m feeling good, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce the conflict between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Even if parents spend less money without their children, the idea of shopping without their kids’ demands might attract more customers.

**Going Up the Wall**
In the past, climbers went to the mountains to climb. Now, people can climb in many places, both indoors and outdoors. A crowd watches in excitement as the French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by two fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is better known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common - The Wall. 
The ability to have these events is thanks to new technology. Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it was important for climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they started to climb on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid getting bored.
Soon, many sports centers built climbing walls using special bricks. One of the first climbing walls was made by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in a corridor at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He created a wall with natural rock set in concrete. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls in the 1970s, but they had some problems. These walls were only straight up and down, while real cliffs have different shapes like overhangs and slanted rocks. Once the walls were built, they could not be changed, and climbers would get tired of the same routes.
In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a new material that could be shaped like the holds on real cliffs. These holds could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started to make climbing walls with steel frames. Steel was lighter than concrete, so it was easier to build overhanging walls. This new system allowed climbers to have many different holds to choose from.

**So You Want to Be an Actor**
If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is a risky choice. Acting is indeed a risky career because there are many actors but not enough jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some people you thought were your friends might think you are making a mistake, while others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice, but this is a personal choice, and you are responsible for your own dreams.
There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no tests to pass, and even after training, there is no guarantee you will get a job. Success depends on luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and rewarding.
Many people ask what talent is. I think talent is a mix of natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. It also depends on a person's courage and belief in what they are doing. 
Why do people want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is when the actor connects with the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform. 
When you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they might not have a clear answer. They know some things about their skills and techniques, but they also understand that their success can change quickly. 
Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. Last month, you might have been without work, doing other jobs. Then, you might get a chance to audition for a role. But even if you really want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often avoid talking about their chances of getting a role. They find ways to cope with the stress of competition and the fear of rejection. No one likes to be rejected, and this fear is present from the moment you start auditioning. 
When you say you are available for acting jobs, you are showing that you are willing and hopefully talented enough. In many ways, it is up to you. If you do not care about your acting career, others may not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**
We are happy to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available. 
A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many places around the world, and she loves exciting food. She also understands what regular cooks can do in their kitchens. The book that made her famous is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book is now a must-have for modern cooks. It gives simple and expert advice on basic and advanced cooking, along with many great recipes that are not boring. This updated book answers the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which one would it be?"
B. Raymond Blanc became a well-known chef in just 15 years. He is the owner of the most famous French restaurant in Britain. To go with his first TV show, "Blanc Mange," he has written a book with the same name. Raymond wants to help everyone become better cooks by showing how and why certain ingredients work together. He believes that cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. His book has over 80 amazing recipes that show this. It is a practical book that explains why some dishes can go wrong and includes some basic food science. Monsieur Blanc loves to cook for others, and this book shows that he is very good at it.
C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that represents the best in French cooking. For the last 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained students to be great cooks. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have published a new book called "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," which has 100 of the school's best recipes. These classic recipes are still fresh and exciting. While Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking, it has also changed some recipes to make them healthier. The book starts with basic kitchen skills and then includes Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools around the world have chosen their famous recipes and shared their secrets.
D. Fast food? No way! Many people think that good food takes a long time to cook. But Nigel Slater, the food editor of The Observer, disagrees. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be good. Nigel believes that it is possible to make something tasty in the time it takes to order a pizza. He has already written two successful books to prove this. In this new book, you will find many delicious recipes that are ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel has written over 200 recipes from around the world in a fun and easy style. Just because he likes fast food doesn’t mean he doesn’t appreciate good food. If you think fast food can’t be great, try his recipes—they are simply delicious!

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, he is 228 cm tall, making him Britain's tallest man.
Every ten years, the average height of people in Europe increases by one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors looked. We are starting to lose the effects of many years of poor diets. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago."
For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started, and this changed everything. Farmers took over many green areas, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories we eat today. This poor diet has harmed our health. 
In Ohio, scientists found that when they started farming corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sick and underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, which was thought to be good, actually caused health problems. However, farming spread because one piece of land could feed many more people than hunting could.
Today, many people are still poorly nourished, but some countries like those in Europe, the US, and Japan are starting to eat better again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a good change, but it also brings problems. 
Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have stayed the same at 190 cm since 1860. Also, legroom in planes and trains seems to be getting smaller, and clothing companies have to change their sizes often. 
The question is: how tall can we get? We cannot keep growing forever. Some scientists think we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, there is a twist. While some people are getting taller because of better nutrition, as a species, we might actually be getting shorter. 
During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, people were a bit rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even when we eat well. As the planet continues to warm, we might shrink even more. So, while some people are growing taller, the overall trend for humanity could be the opposite.

**A NEW LIFE**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the City, it became boring. No one was having fun anymore. I didn’t plan to leave my job yet, but then I lost it suddenly. I didn’t get a lot of money when I left, but it was enough to start my farm. I met the head chef of a local hotel, which is one of the best in the country. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but I still work long hours, about 80 to 90 a week, and I’m still selling a product."
**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby and found it more exciting than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. He talked to a career counselor who was surprised when Ron said he didn’t want to go back to his old job. Most people in their forties need to work for money. Ron and his wife moved to the north of England, where they didn’t know anyone. They left their friends behind, but they still keep in touch, and many friends visit them.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. She enjoyed being a lawyer and earned a lot of money, but the hours were very long. She didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even more, so she left. Many people thought she would get bored, but she hasn’t. She says having deadlines helps her stay busy. In her fashion business, there is always a lot to do, so she keeps a strict schedule. She feels happier and less stressed now, but she misses talking to colleagues. She loves being responsible for her work. If she does a bad job, she knows it’s her fault. When she worked for a company, she cared, but now she cares even more because her name is on everything.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance at 22, but he didn’t find it rewarding. In 1989, he almost lost his job, so he decided to resign and travel for a year. During that year, he thought about what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners about starting a business. He knew he needed qualifications to change careers, so he took massage courses. Then he got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He has no regrets about his decision. He feels more in control of his life now and enjoys having peace of mind.

**A Winning Game**
Two brothers are discovering that their childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two bearded brothers in their forties, are at home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, playing a game called pichenotte. This game is special to them because their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought it from Quebec, Canada, to the USA. The family played pichenotte every weekend and holiday, and they always had a lot of fun.
When the family moved to New Mexico, they kept playing pichenotte with the board that their grandfather made from old wooden crates. Visitors were often curious about the game because it was unknown in the southern USA. Three years ago, Dave noticed that their old pichenotte board was damaged, so he decided to make a new one. His new board was beautiful, and soon relatives and friends wanted their own.
One night, the brothers took a new board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. At first, people thought it was a silly game, but then they started to play and enjoyed it. When people asked about the game’s history, Dave researched it. He found that pichenotte likely comes from India, where a similar game called 'carroms' is played. This game changed into 'squails' in Britain, and British people brought it to Canada. The name pichenotte comes from the French-Canadian version of the game in Quebec.
Pichenotte can be played by two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces, or 'pucks', which they flick across a round board using their fingers. If a puck goes into a small hole, it scores 20 points. There are also three rings around the hole that score 15, 10, and 5 points. The game has eight small posts that act as obstacles, and it usually lasts about two minutes.
Seeing how popular the game was at the bar, the Lagasse brothers made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Many people came to watch and buy the game, and soon they started holding championships with a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup'. As more people learned about the game, the brothers sold boards quickly.
They decided to make pichenotte their full-time business. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards so far. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12 kg, and is 1 cm thick. Norm says, "They're very durable because they need to last a long time." Each board costs $595 and can be bought from their website.
Currently, there are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows about the game. However, the brothers hope that one day their garage will be home to a luxury car instead of tools and wood. For now, they are happy to spend their free time playing the game they love and hope will bring them success.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**
When you first come to the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this was just a flat piece of land covered in weeds. For a long time, people thought it was useless. But one man, with the help of his wife, worked very hard to change this land into the beautiful village you see today. 
Many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into a lovely landscape. Machines like bulldozers helped, but a lot of hard work was also done by hand. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. Hundreds of trees and bushes were planted, chosen carefully to survive near the sea and strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from Canada and New Zealand.
Colin Sims created the whole village and made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, treated wood, and plastic to last in all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn about these materials, but soon he became an expert himself. 
You will notice that everything is built to the same scale, and even the smallest details are carefully made. This took a lot of patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is very popular and is known for its high quality and good care. The methods used here have been copied in other model villages in England and even taught in some colleges.
All the buildings in the village show traditional British styles and are not based on one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, which is a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. As you walk around, you will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition.
Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models, as any damage can take a long time to fix. You can take photos from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead.
To make your visit more fun, you will find buttons in front of some models. Press these buttons to see the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your comments. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more interesting display. We also want to know if any models did not meet your expectations, as we are always updating them.
We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don’t forget to tell your friends about us!

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the rules set by newspaper editors. While some pop stars do take pictures with paparazzi sometimes, this is not common. More often, these pictures cause great harm to famous people when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle these problems. These pictures are rarely in the public interest. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve a crime? How does a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony help keep people safe? The actress has complained about long-distance photos before, and since she was in a hotel, where people expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she did not take any action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation. 
The PCC should also look into a recent shocking story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on this and other unfair stories? This seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers. Other newspapers would report on this, and it would be on TV and radio. The public would not support these newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such stories. Photographers would also be affected, as they would not be able to hide and take pictures of celebrities anymore. 
If the PCC decided to act like a "police officer," there would be some problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it talk to the victim and encourage them to complain? And if the person still did not want to complain, should the PCC still investigate? Celebrities and royal family members might expect the PCC to take action on their stories, and they could be upset if it does not happen. The job of the PCC is very big. How could it monitor all of the British press, including national and regional newspapers and magazines? 
There is also the issue of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Many people just want to forget about it and move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story that they do not want to become public if they complain. In this way, the PCC could become a problem for them. 
One British comedian faced issues with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He did not complain then, and he also did not complain when he and his family were photographed during a holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper would publish the pictures again with a new story about his anger, saying they thought it was just a joke and that he would find it funny because he is a comedian. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many college graduates get advice when they start their first job. This article talks about what to think about when looking for a second job. We are not talking about people who want a temporary job while looking for a permanent one or those who leave a job they don’t like after a few weeks. Instead, we focus on those who are ready to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do.
What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You should think about whether you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to a job with more responsibility, or change to a different field. Whatever you choose, be careful when picking your second job. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years. Future employers will look closely at this job when you apply for your next one. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, this job should help you grow, develop your skills, and give you more responsibilities.
If you want to travel, now might be a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Employers will be happy to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again soon.
Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers in her first year after leaving St. Aldate's College. She says it was a great first job because the people were supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her typing skills. However, there was no chance for promotion. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.
Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more skilled, and my job has really grown." From the start, her boss wanted to help her develop. Although her job title is the same, her responsibilities have changed. She now does most of the correspondence and budgets and answers questions from many people, including company chairmen and those wanting to start their own business. Brenda involves her in all her work and gives her specific projects and events to organize.

**Confident People: What’s Their Secret?**
Confident people may seem like they were born that way, but most say it is a skill they learned. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.
**A. Jenny**  
When I left school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. When I was about twenty-five, I helped at my daughter’s school. I was nervous, but I did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I was very anxious, but my confidence grew over time. Working at the school changed my life and helped me become more outgoing.
**B. Michaela**  
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive. I learned that to be confident, you need to believe in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don’t feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When I face something difficult, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel less confident, so I talk to myself to calm those fears.
**C. Lisa**  
People think I am very confident, but I often feel scared inside. I learned to look confident because it is important in my job in TV. Interviewing people showed me that many of us feel nervous in important situations. My mother once told me that everyone is too busy worrying about themselves to notice me. I remember this advice often. I also believe you gain confidence by facing your fears. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I could handle anything.
**D. Barbara**  
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I have built it up over the years. If you keep working and learn from mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone will like you. It’s important to like yourself and not try to be what others want. My company offers training courses, which have helped me feel better about myself. Setting small goals helps too, as it shows you are achieving something.
**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings without speaking up. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I started working in politics, I was very nervous about speaking in public. I told myself that many people do this every day, so I could too. Writing down my points helped me feel more prepared. I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking in public. The real secret to confidence is to keep telling yourself, “Nothing is impossible.”

**Visit to Malaysia**
Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. "You have to keep it," he said. "It's traditional - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it... and I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All the kites were 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat in the shade of the tall trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, looking at Malaysia's biggest kite festival.
In the middle of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A line of nervous competitors held the lines of their kites, waiting for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites flew into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts for five days every year. Each person entered four different kite designs, which were judged on decoration, stability in the air, and how well they flew. 
"Flying kites isn't hard," said Adnan, "but making them takes real skill. Come to my house, and I'll show you how to make one." I received five invitations that day, and I decided to accept his. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a big, nice room. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, through beautiful mountains with thick rainforests.
I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, I saw a sign that said: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before I started walking, it would have been good to know that most of the path was steep and slippery. When I reached the track, I met a man named Baba, who took care of a kitchen and some bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects under my thin mattress. 
At night, it was very dark, and I heard many different sounds. A waterfall was loud nearby, and many creatures were moving and making noise. In the morning, I saw a great view of five green mountain ranges. In the afternoon, it rained. First, there was wind, then lightning hit the trees. I got soaked. As I slid down the hill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the rain. I also worried about my car getting washed away (it sometimes happens) and if I would drown if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the hill.
In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But they were friendly. Kelantan is known for its kites, but I will remember it more for the kindness of its people.

**What kind of shopper are you?**
We all go shopping, but we have different shopping styles. Do you know what type of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.
A. **Melanie, 22, dancer**  
"I love shopping! I can't spend enough money. When I have cash, I go shopping and feel happy. I can't walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We are both addicted to shopping!"
B. **Brenda, 40, office manager**  
"I don’t like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I take my kids shopping for clothes, but we all have different tastes, so it’s not fun. I don’t spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and tell my husband I spent less than I really did."
C. **Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
"I only shop for what I need. I hate shopping and only go when I have to. When I do go, I know exactly what I want and I don’t want anything else. Shopping makes me tired, and I would rather be doing something else."
D. **Anita, 35, TV producer**  
"I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and try to shop quickly. However, I have bought things I didn’t really need, so maybe I’m careful but sometimes make mistakes."
E. **Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
"I really don’t like shopping. I find it hard to find clothes I want, and the shops are too noisy and messy. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often because I get most of my clothes for free. For food, I go to the supermarket once a week and do it quickly."
F. **Lisa, 22, actress**  
"I’m a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually go with a specific item in mind, but if I see something I like, I buy it."
G. **Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
"I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy a lot. I usually know what I want and don’t spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I feel worse because I spent too much money."
H. **Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
"I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too busy. I’m a careful shopper. I have an idea of what I want and I look in different shops to find the best price. It takes me a long time!"
I. **Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
"I don’t like shopping, maybe because I work in the city and the shops don’t interest me anymore. When I have to shop, I go but don’t try things on because it’s too much trouble. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t mind making mistakes."
